Text: Good: -It works well, and the interface is nice. -It is also very nice to be able set it up to erase with your finger (after taking notes with your stylus wacom or active based). It is relatively easy to export to jpg or locally to the device or google drive. -There is a cast button that lets you cast to google devices... like nest hubs and chrome cast... I have not tried in the office with Google Meet conference hardware, but will update when I do. -They don't have their own weird cloud. This app is standalone and does not need an account with whoever devs Squid. -You can lasso inserted photos and move them Bad: -The erase with your finger option is negated by the fact that when the palm rejection doesn't work (which happens often), ends up erasing your notes (I guess this is more problematic for me since I am left handed). I had to turn it off. -There is no option to auto backup to Google Drive or OneDrive. This is particularly upsetting, because unless you remember to manually backup, you may lose your device and your notes. To do that you would have to use Dropbox or Box (i am not about to get another service just for this app). Also, given that those two are the most popular cloud services for business, it makes it impossible for me to propose the adoption of this app at work. -This app is subscription based. Premium features cost per month/year... not single purchase like INKredible. I guess you can buy features one at a time, but that doesn't seem like a good idea to me. I am still on the fence of which app to keep.
text: good it works well and the interface is nice it is also very nice to be able set it up to erase with your finger after taking notes with your stylus wacom or active based it is relatively easy to export to jpg or locally to the device or google drive there is a cast button that lets you cast to google devices like nest hubs and chrome cast i have not tried in the office with google meet conference hardware but will update when i do they dont have their own weird cloud this app is standalone and does not need an account with whoever devs squid you can lasso inserted photos and move them bad the erase with your finger option is negated by the fact that when the palm rejection doesnt work which happens often ends up erasing your notes i guess this is more problematic for me since i am left handed i had to turn it off there is no option to auto backup to google drive or onedrive this is particularly upsetting because unless you remember to manually backup you may lose your device and your notes to do that you would have to use dropbox or box i am not about to get another service just for this app also given that those two are the most popular cloud services for business it makes it impossible for me to propose the adoption of this app at work this app is subscription based premium features cost per monthyear not single purchase like inkredible i guess you can buy features one at a time but that doesnt seem like a good idea to me i am still on the fence of which app to keep

Text: I use a Huawei M5 Lite and active stylus. Been using the free version of Squid for two years for note-taking on projects, scribbled diagrams and snipped crosswords and sudokus. It’s not blighted by adverts or excessive prompting to go premium, no limitations on notebook sizes – I’ve >130 pages in one notebook – and no petty restrictions that limit its usefulness. I use pdf export to transfer notebooks and will upgrade to premium to use Dropbox and other features. Thoroughly recommend it!

Text: What I like about this app is the limitless canvas available, which I find useful. The reason for this is when I'm doing mathematical calculations it's handy to be able to keep the last step in sight when scrolling down for more space. I imagine the same thing applies when making designs so this app overcomes the restrictions of a cell phone screen. It' s also has a fairly simple interface.

Text: I'm disappointed. Lines are jagged - there is a feature request for 7 years to fix this. Few tools there and yet you need multiple clicks for tool changing - try draw simple circle/rectangle/line diagram (requested by 600+ users more then one year ago). Blending method of highlighter tool is lowering contrast and readability of highlighted text. In addition text written on a highlighted line is rendered differently. If you move previously written text on a highlighted line, text is still rendered as it would below highlight. There are some interesting features like different paper styles (lines, squares, dots etc), I like workflow based on a vector engine - size changing, colors etc. However I don't understand how application with subscriber model and long history still have so immature feature bugs for such a long time. I'll bee looking for an alternative.

Text: Works fantastic with Samsung Tablet SM-P550 and S Pen. Does not work well with Lenovo USI pen and Lenovo Chromebook Duet. USI pens supposed to have like 4096 levels of pressure sensitivity. Text: Squid has many great features-it's very smooth, provides quick shortcuts for changing tools, colors, etc, and has decent customizability in terms of page zoom, template, and pen buttons-but unfortunately there are a few missing parts which are almost dealbreakers for me. First, there's no continuous scroll option, so it's very inconvenient to flip through the pages of a pdf. Second, there is no sync between devices. Finally, the file management system is limited to just notebooks and notes.

Text: I am trying this because I got a 2-in-1 chromebook, but it really makes me miss Lecture Notes, which has been my favorite note taking app for years. Good: There is no lag when writing. There are several background patterns to choose from. Cons: The writing often shows as shaky, even though I have a pretty steady hand. I can't seem to get it to ignore my hand resting on the screen when I'm writing with a stylus. I don't understand the scroll. I have now twice lost my notes while writing, because it is set to "infinite" page size, and some gesture from my hand caused me to scroll apparently miles away from my writing. If I "print" the page, I can see that the writing is still there somewhere, but I cannot find it by zooming and scrolling around. There doesn't seem to be a way to ask for help, only a page for offering suggestions or making feature requests. That's why I'm writing here.

Text: I use the app to replace blackboard while giving math lectures at a university (over Zoom). I typically create partially filled pdf slides and then write on them while lecturing, using a 10.5 inch android tablet with pen. Three things would vastly improve the app for me: 1) while the pen is hovering over the screen, there is a tiny circle. However, it's so small that the student's can barely see it. I don't know if this is something that can be done inside the app, but I would love if I could change the way this circle looks and use it as a pointer. 2) The blue bar on top takes up about 20% of the screen while not containing anything too useful. The app looks like it thinks that my screen is much smaller than it actually is. The bar doesn't go away when my tablet is connected over Zoom and I am sharing its screen. 3) I change colors often. I like the preselected colors and appreciate that it takes only 3 taps to change color (unlike other apps), but I would appreciate if the (much thinner version of) the blue bar on top had a few color disks to choose from (of colors customizable by the user) and color change would take one tap, not 3. 4) The last complaint is just a minor one, but maybe easily fixable: when I write on my slides (created with beamer, LaTeX, of standard size) and I want to add a page, I struggle to find the correct size to match the other pages. As a result, the resulting class notes have pages that are suddenly twice as big, or the pen becomes too thin, etc... Otherwise, great job, this is a very nice app!

Text: I have been using NoteShelf since Aug 2020. I use note writing apps a lot for studying AI and stats (a lot of equations, diagrams and images) so it is an absolute critical piece of software, besides having decent hardware (Tab S7). After all these months, I finally decided to make the jump over to Squid. Bought the in-app tool pack, backup and PDF import.The overall experience have been great thus far. #################################### PLUS:: [ Palm rejection is MUCH MUCH better on Squid than on NoteShelf. I think it might be due to Squid requiring 2 fingers for pan. This was a MAJOR PITA for me using NoteShelf. ] - [ My backup EMR pen from my Likebook Muses worked way better than on NoteShelf. Even the eraser works on Squid, which doesn't work on NoteShelf. ] - [ I screenshot a lot (off lecture videos) for my notes. On Noteshelf, my palm kept accidentally selecting my screenshot-images because the app registered it as a long press. On Squid, selection of images requires the use of the lasso tool, so no such problem. ] - [ Pressure sensitivity works well. Makes my handwriting look a lot better. ] - [ Squid's shape tool is a lot more use-able compared to Noteshelf. I can be very precise. ] - [ I exported my NoteShelf notes as PDFs. Squid opened them up like a charm. ] - [ If we put font choice aside, typing text with a bluetooth keyboard is a lot less buggy on Squid vis-a-vis NoteShelf. ] - [ 1000% zoom. I can pack a lot into an A4 sheet. Especially useful when writing cheat-sheets. ] - [ There is backup to a local folder. This plays well for me as I have FolderSync Pro. No such feature on NoteShelf. ] - [ I can set what action to take when I press my S-pen button. No such setting on NoteShelf. ] ####################### CONS:: [ Eraser size needs improving. The smallest setting (1mm) is still too big when you zoom in to 600%-1000%. Only way to work around is to not write at such high zoom levels. ] - [ Eraser shape is square. NoteShelf is circle, a shape that is a lot easier to get into the little nooks and crannies, especially on a page pack full of notes ] - [ One extra tap to switch out to other tools (i.e. lasso, highlight or shape tool.) ] - [ Lasso selection can be a bit tricky if handwriting and image are too close. Noteshelf doesn't have this issue: I usually just draw a small lasso circle in the middle of the image to avoid all the handwrite all around. ] - [ Not sure if the automated backup is actually working *Testing in progress ] - [ Cloud backup ONLY has Dropbox and Box. No Google Drive. NoteShelf has Drive, Evernote and Dropbox. ] - [ Whenever you zoom, the zoom % box (that lets you know what percentage zoom you're at and to lock it if you wish) is right smack in the center-top. Very irritating when you're trying to write from top-down. With NoteShelf, I was at least able to drag it into the corner. This box should really default to a corner. ] - [ No audio record. Noteshelf has it. ] - [ Access to other page templates requires a monthly subscription on Squid. Noteshelf's page templates are free. With PDF import, this is easy to go around on Squid: I just export as PDF from NoteShelf's template and use it as and when when on Squid. ] - [ No bookmarking. Noteshelf has it. ]

Text: As someone coming from an iPad to a Tab S7+, Squid is a great alternative to notability, arguably the best note taking app on iPad. Squid is very responsive and the writing comes out clean. I like the organization options and having it as a PDF editor is great too. I have to take massive points off for one single thing that is such a downer that it frustrates me on an otherwise great app. This app, a note taking app, is not in fullscreen mode. That's right. The navigation bar is there at all times. It's incredibly frustrating to accidentally hit any of the buttons on the navigation bar which I have already done plenty of times in my first day using this app. An option for fullscreen mode would make this app so much better. As is, the navigation bar being there is massive points off and, maybe over time, a deal breaker. For now, I've resorted to using a fullscreen immersive app that forces the device to have it in fullscreen mode at all times when activated. A workaround, but not a solution.
text: as someone coming from an ipad to a tab s squid is a great alternative to notability arguably the best note taking app on ipad squid is very responsive and the writing comes out clean i like the organization options and having it as a pdf editor is great too i have to take massive points off for one single thing that is such a downer that it frustrates me on an otherwise great app this app a note taking app is not in fullscreen mode thats right the navigation bar is there at all times its incredibly frustrating to accidentally hit any of the buttons on the navigation bar which i have already done plenty of times in my first day using this app an option for fullscreen mode would make this app so much better as is the navigation bar being there is massive points off and maybe over time a deal breaker for now ive resorted to using a fullscreen immersive app that forces the device to have it in fullscreen mode at all times when activated a workaround but not a solution

Text: I've been using Squid every day for two different classes, so about 6 months total, and it's really a great app. I can only really think of some minor suggestions for improvement, such as sync across devices, and the ability to add to remove elements after selecting them with the selection tool. And it would be nice to have the ability to lock some items in place, so they don't get moved or selected accidentally later. I often make tables and being the force them into the background after drawing them, similar to how an imported PDF functions, would be nice. That's about all I can think of for now. But this app is so much better than all the others I've looked it, it's hard to complain too much. I especially like how it works so well with my S Pen to suppress any contact my hand makes from disturbing my canvas.

Text: This is generally a very good app. I mostly use it for marking up PDFs, which it is quick at and saves them within the app as a separate file, rather than overwriting the original PDF. You can later export the marked up PDF which is great. The two most annoying things I find is, firstly, there is no option to swipe to the next page. Most of the time I don't need to do it, but it would be a nice option that is available in other apps. The more annoying thing, that I haven't found in another app and so would really make this app stand out is the ability to navigate a PDF using the built in bookmarks. I am often trying to navigate a multi-thousand page PDF and find myself lost only having the option to look at all the pages in a thumbnail view or to scroll the page number (not even type one in). If a bookmark navigation feature was added I really think that would transform my usage of this app.

Text: Good app overall. Text: Best note-taking experience on Android/Chrome OS I've found. Handwriting is quick and smooth. Two issues keep this from being a five star app: 1. No vertical scrolling. Pressing buttons to turn the page is distracting, and takes me out of the flow of my work. 2. File management for .PDFs is clunky. I have to import a .PDF and edit it, then overwrite the original. On a Chromebook, this is doubly annoying because there's no native access to the Chrome OS Google Drive. Keep up the good work!
text: best notetaking experience on androidchrome os ive found handwriting is quick and smooth two issues keep this from being a five star app no vertical scrolling pressing buttons to turn the page is distracting and takes me out of the flow of my work file management for pdfs is clunky i have to import a pdf and edit it then overwrite the original on a chromebook this is doubly annoying because theres no native access to the chrome os google drive keep up the good work

Text: The ideas are fantastic, but some annoying bugs stop this from being outstanding. 1) the infinite canvas applies only bottom and right of the canvas. Not really infinite canvas, in my opinion. Text: A pretty solid note taking app. Stylus support is really solid, and there are some nice workflow gestures while in a document. The interface is also pretty straightforward and doesn't look too dated. However there appears to be a couple of basic features missing, such as searching for notes by title, some sort of gesture for going to the next page in a document, and allowing to vertically scroll through a document. I also don't like how you can't see where you're scrolling.

Text: This is definitely the best note taking app on Android. There are tons of options for paper type (lined, grid, engineering, sports layouts, etc.) and great options for writing with colors, shapes and lines. Adding pictures and screenshots is very easy. Using it on a Samsung Galaxy Tab with S-Pen is a breeze. I used it for 1.5 semesters of college and absolutely loved it. That's where my biggest issue with the app comes in. There is no syncing of your notes to any account (there is backup and restore, but the functionality is not the same). I had my tablet stolen halfway through this past spring semester and lost all of my notes from the past 1.5 semesters. While I could have backed up the notes, there should seriously be a sync functionality so you can edit notes on multiple devices and even view on a computer. Overall very good app. Just backup your notes (And please add this sync functionality, Steadfast!).
text: this is definitely the best note taking app on android there are tons of options for paper type lined grid engineering sports layouts etc and great options for writing with colors shapes and lines adding pictures and screenshots is very easy using it on a samsung galaxy tab with spen is a breeze i used it for semesters of college and absolutely loved it thats where my biggest issue with the app comes in there is no syncing of your notes to any account there is backup and restore but the functionality is not the same i had my tablet stolen halfway through this past spring semester and lost all of my notes from the past semesters while i could have backed up the notes there should seriously be a sync functionality so you can edit notes on multiple devices and even view on a computer overall very good app just backup your notes and please add this sync functionality steadfast

Recording the Lectures....

But as is, its intuitive and very worth trying.

Text: Edit 2: Nice non-apology. You guys can keep your monopoly on handwriten note apps on Chromebook, I'm switching back to Windows with OneNote.   Edit: Developers have sat on the app without providing new features. Subscriptions are a two way street, users pay developers a reoccuring fee in return for improvements. Sure there is the occasional "bug fix and optimization" update, but where is the Google Drive sync? Where is the handwriting search? Compared to other apps like LectureNotes and OneNote, Squid is very minimal and honestly it just doesn't compare.   Compared to LectureNotes, the pricing for tools is a somewhat big investment. LectureNotes lets you get all the features with just 1 payment while this makes you pay separately for tools, pdf import, cloud, etc.

Text: Overall, It's a pretty efficient note taking app. Lots of colors for ink/ highlighting options, import pdfs/export notes as pdfs (very cool), plus uploading to my google drive. Tons of different paper options as well. The only thing I wish it did better was straight lines and shapes. As a physics major, I do alot of diagramming, and would ideally like straight lines. In order to make straight lines or perfect shapes, you have to entirely select a different tool, then switch back to the regular pen. And even then you can only choose between two shapes and straight lines. I wish this were a) more seamless or atleast b) provided more options (like circles instead of just elliptical objects), or parabolas (or even better graph plotting!), or maybe just stars and stuff. But that's really the only complaint I have with it. Everything else is awesome.

Text: On a Pixel Slate, this is a great app.  There are just a couple of things that are almost deal breakers for me.  I'm sure most of it is user-error, but I cannot get the palm rejection to work for the life of me.  As I draw with the stylus, it's constantly trying to multi-task, zoom or other things. I wish there was a quick and easy way to turn on palm rejection.  I also wish there were more pen types like in INKredible.   The other big missing feature is the ability to back up to Google Drive as a cloud option.  That seems pretty reasonable since, as I'm on an Android device I will clearly have a Google Drive account.  Having used both iOS and Android tablets, I think this is the best one on Android, but I still feel like GoodNotes on iOS is the best, overall experience and has some great features Squid should take a look at...

Text: The best writing app among samsung notes, one note (free android version) simply because I can set page size and organize my notes well.   UPDATE: After using this app for almost 2 years now, I must say that this is still my app of choice for taking notes in school. Nice colors, for smooth writing and prints fantastically. The biggest problem with other apps is their inability to provide a straightforward way to get notes into PDF properly for printing purposes. Squid is the way to go for taking notes in school, writing assignments and printing.  Only thing I would change in this app is a way to save my notes to the SD card. After almost 2 years, I am running out of space on the pre-installed storage. Also, the lack of a way to export an entire notebook means that I have to manually export each note as PDF to copy that notebook to my long-term storage. That is very tedious but looks like I have no other way to save my notes and free-up space.  My advice for newbies is to export your notes daily or weekly and at the end of a semester delete the notebook to save space. You will thank me later.  Thank the developers for a very useful note-taking app.
text: the best writing app among samsung notes one note free android version simply because i can set page size and organize my notes well update after using this app for almost years now i must say that this is still my app of choice for taking notes in school nice colors for smooth writing and prints fantastically the biggest problem with other apps is their inability to provide a straightforward way to get notes into pdf properly for printing purposes squid is the way to go for taking notes in school writing assignments and printing only thing i would change in this app is a way to save my notes to the sd card after almost years i am running out of space on the preinstalled storage also the lack of a way to export an entire notebook means that i have to manually export each note as pdf to copy that notebook to my longterm storage that is very tedious but looks like i have no other way to save my notes and freeup space my advice for newbies is to export your notes daily or weekly and at the end of a semester delete the notebook to save space you will thank me later thank the developers for a very useful notetaking app

Text: Excellent app for capturing my handwriting! I use it on a Chromebook Pro, and it's even smoother than writing on paper. I'm able to easily organize my notes into notebooks, add pages to my notes, and even change whether I'm writing with notebook paper lines, graph paper, or plane white. And did I mention you can change the colors and thickness of the ink? Now, I'm not a fan of subscribing to things - the freemium version of Squid will do almost everything you need for notetaking, and I'm very happy with it. I did some in-app purchases for typing on the screen and adding shapes, and those have been worthwhile and affordable. --- Update: I now also have the app on my phone, and alas there is no way to sync the notes from my phone and my Chromebook. However, both my phone and Chromebook automatically backup my notes to Dropbox every day as PDF's, and it's easy to export the really important notes to specific folders in my Google Drive (and other online platforms) as needed. Plus you can't beat the control for line thickness, color, and page background. Granted, you get even better backgrounds (including daily planner) if you sign up for premium, and I can't afford that. But with a few in-app purchases you can get PDF and JPG import, which will them provide any background you could possibly want. I actually use the app to take photos and then draw sketches over the photos. Once the sketch is done, I copy the lines over to a plain white background, and voila - a nice cartoon image. Do if you're looking for a versatile and dependable notes app with automatic backup, I think this may be your best bet.

Text: I thought this was a good program with smooth writing, so I bought it to be able to import pdf's and write on them. I paid the $10 for a yearly subscription.   Yes, it allows you to write on the pdf's, but the refresh is horrible, I imported a 10 page pdf, and the tablet slowly redraws each page when I move between them. Should not have half the screen disappear. No, it's not the tablet. I use One Note by Microsoft, and I have none of these issues. Honestly not worth it.   I would recommend One Note, which is free and writes smoothly (plus you have access to all your notes on the web for free), or Xodo, which lets you highlight pdf's (I imported a 2000 page document, no issues scrolling entire document), also can add text, draw, and more. Going back to that, should have never left. Figured a paid app would be better than a free one, I was wrong. Really would like a refund.

Text: I've rewritten this review several times now before realizing that google play ui is poorly set up in tablets (the reason for my losing my review writing progress several times) so now I'm writing it elsewhere and pasting it in later. Anyway, I've been compiling a list of features I want from Squid, in a Squid note (for irony or something). But for this review, I'd like to suggest that the devs of Squid try downloading INKredible, the leading competitor for handwritten notes (on Android at least; idk for iOS). There are a lot of similarities and differences, and pros and cons for each, but ultimately I chose to keep Squid. It wasn't an easy choice though, and I hope for Squid to improve to a point where it /would/ be an easy choice. That is, for Squid to implement all the "pros" without adding any of the "cons" of its competitor.

Text: It's a little less functional than I'd like it to be, but for free it comes with enough to draw in different colors and thicknesses and embed images. The strokes with the Pixel Pen are pressure sensitive to increase and decrease the thickness too. You have to pay a couple bucks for the rest of the templates, but it's not a bad price for an app. You can increase page size and change the dimensions to that of different paper standards, add lines or grids, and export to pdf, jpeg, or png. You can also add multiple pages to a single note and organize notes into different notebooks. Works with just a finger too! Lastly, (and I like this feature a lot), you can import pdfs. Great for doing homework right on the assignment. Feature request: add layers for additional drawing tools. I use this app mostly for dungeons and dragons mapping (mirrorring screen with a Chromecast), and having layers would make it infinitely easier to handle fogs of war and the like.

Text: I never write app reviews, but I love Squid. I actually bought a reMarkable recently (a dedicated note-taking device), and having used Squid I just couldn't get into it... Works great on a pixelbook, super low latency pen integration. Love the erase w/ finger feature. Add a search feature based on handwriting recognition (I don't need to export to text, I just want to be able to search my notes), and it'd be perfect for me. Would also be great if the pinned orientation feature worked better in tablet mode on ChromeOS - I keep accidentally hitting buttons in the dock/tray (but this is more a fault of ChromeOS than Squid, IMO).

Text: I gave it an honest shot. While it is a beautiful app, it lacks the basic staples needed for success. No collaboration, no ability to rearrange notes within a notebook, and most importantly, NO SYNC. This is almost laughable! What powerful note taking app doesn't sync? Doing manual backups and restorations is not only archaic, it is a major liability. How easy is it to lose an entire year of work by accidentally resorting an incorrect backup? Come on guys, this is a no brainer. UPDATE: I dropped from three stars to two stars. I have lost numerous documents because of the lack of syncing options. Also, there has been more than enough time for Squid to update their app to allow automatic syncing. While I understand you can set an automatic cloud update, this is still not helpful because you have to manually restore a backup EVERY SINGLE TIME you use a different device. It is ridiculous.

Text: pen support on the pixelbook is great, writes much more smoothly than in keep. However, many critical features that could make this the perfect note-taking app for chrome os are missing. For instance, you cannot scroll continuously through pages of pdfs, and you can't have more than one note open at once (for instance, marking up a pdf textbook and taking notes at the same time). The app also does not have access to local files on the computer, although I have read that this is an issue with android apps in chrome os. Squid does not support syncing to other devices or to Google drive. I have also been experiencing some crashing while working on larger notes. Otherwise, out of all the mediocre/broken ways of taking notes and drawing on chrome os that I have tried so far, this is the least mediocre/broken

Text: This is a really outstanding note taking app for android, if not the best. Taking notes with an active pen is really easy and practical. The interface is really nice and simple. Also a fair price for premium options which really are usefull. The fact that pdfs are exported without being splitted into a4 format (or any format for that matter) is really nice, something that can't be done in onenote for example. Some functions, however, could be better. It would be nice to import PDF files within a note so that you can annotate the PDF file (instead of importing PDF pages seperately as a new page). Also, it would also be nice to have some more figures that you can draw besides the line, square and circle (for example, 2d or 3d axis, triangle, arrows, dotted line etc.) and the option of filling a figure with a certain color. Another thing that can be better are the sync options, OneDrive or GoogleDrive are currently not supported for example.

Text: I really love this app, it is so helpful for taking notes in my college courses. There are, however, a few features that I wish could be added/modified. It would be nice if you could erase specific areas of something you've written or drawn, instead of erasing everything that I wrote/drew prior to lifting my pen (ex: cursive). I also wish that it were an option to turn handwriting into text and be able to convert it into a Google Doc for easier edits later on. I love handwriting notes because I feel like I can retain the information better, but sometimes, I like the look of typed notes better and I don't always have time to type my notse after writing them. Lastly, it would be really nice to be able to multitask while using the app. I often watch lecture videos and read my electronic textbooks on my Google Pixelbook while taking notes on the screen, and only being able to do one or the other in tablet mode is not very efficient. I would really appreciate it if some of these concerns could be addressed. I think a few adjustments would make this app even more awesome!

Text: Good app, handles the basics nicely. I'm definitely able to use this to get work done and for the most part it stays out of my way. I will mention, since sometimes the devs read these, that I find the UI to be a bit clunky at times. For instance, I am often transfering between different modes (pencil, highlight, etc) and each transfer takes two button presses followed by a menu-clearing action. I really feel like this should be doable in a single action. Additionally, I am often times switching between different colors/thicknesses or have things that I am copying and pasting regularly. Two very useful features would be (a) color/line-thickness presets for both shapes and writing, and (b) a 'palette' where figures I have drawn can be saved for later use. A walk through of (b) would be: i. I draw a figure and decide to save it for later ii. I highlight the figure and touch button 'add-to-palette', adding the highlighted figure. iii. Later, I want to reuse my figure. I select the palette icon which presents a dropdown of thumbnail icons of each figure. iv. I select one figure and it pastes to the screen

Text: The note taking app I've been searching for! This app includes support for PDF markup, pressure-sensitive styli, images, geometry (rectangles, loops & lines), selection tool, infinite canvas, and tons of other options. My only wish was that this also came on the Windows Store so I could view/sync my notes on my computer. The premium version is easily worth five times the price they charge. Notes never become blurry thanks to the vector-based build. It would be nice if it were possible to pin toolbars (like the color and tool picker) open so that changing ink color—or switching between the pen and selection tool—are just one tap away. Such a feature would be fantastic for taking detailed notes during more fast-paced lectures.

rotating selected objects.

subscription!

Text:
I think this app is awesome! I love that it has (1) the option to buy 
outright only the upgrade options you require, (2) the ability to create 
folders for notes (3) the import pdf option (I used that straight away!) 
(4) Saving & exporting WITHOUT re cloud - essential for those of us with 
confidential info, (5) great export options, (7) page sizes that expand in 
any direction you want(7) easy change in colours (8) lots of options to set 
how use gestures & stylus, & (9) fantastically small export file sizes. I 
would have given a 5 star rating if you could (1) choose the default folder 
you could have it open in, (2) have subfolders (3) be able to see the full 
name of a note when in a folder (4) choose to see the notes as a list 
rather than a thumbnail & MOST OF ALL, (5) a textbox where can wrap text & 
adjust the size & shape of the entry. This problem with the textbox going 
off in one line ad infinitum is a fault at needs to be corrected. 
Otherwise, my team have all chosen Squid as their default work tool to take 
clinical notes with clients in the field using their Samsung Note8 phones. 
If the textbox issue was fixed, the app would be perfect for our needs! 
Thanks for having the best option available.

Text:
Squid is the only non Google app that seems to be optimised for the stylus 
on the Google Pixelbook. It is very smooth and a great experience to 
write/sketch/diagram with. The negatives for me are that you get a limited 
set of backgrounds to use. If you want to use more or import your own, you 
can't just upgrade to a one off premium version. You have to purchase a 
monthly subscription which is just not worth it. This one money making 
measure for me limits the usefulness of this app. I have purchased the 
tools upgrade for £2.89. This lets me use all the tools (highlighter, etc.) 
I would have like a similar upgrade option for the backgrounds too but 
sadly not the case. I am still therefore on the lookout for an alternative 
that offers more freedom for a one off upgrade cost.

Text:
I tried lots of different Handwriting programs. Squid was not my first 
choice, but it did a few things better than all the others. The main thing 
was that it worked tolerably at a high resolution on my tablet. Others were 
far too slow to work at my top resolution. The second thing that it did was 
that I could import and export PDF's. Other programs had other features 
that I wanted, but did not need. For example, Squid did not zoom, but that 
really did not matter because I did not need it. Still others handled 
drawings better or had more robust file management, but these were usually 
coupled with intolerably slow Handwriting rendering. Squid had the features 
that I needed and worked fine at high resolution. I have used Squid as my 
Handwriting program for several months and I have grown to like it quite a 
bit over time. There are many improvements I could suggest, but nothing I 
suggest would matter over what it already does and does well.
text: i tried lots of different handwriting programs squid was not my first choice but it did a few things better than all the others the main thing was that it worked tolerably at a high resolution on my tablet others were far too slow to work at my top resolution the second thing that it did was that i could import and export pdfs other programs had other features that i wanted but did not need for example squid did not zoom but that really did not matter because i did not need it still others handled drawings better or had more robust file management but these were usually coupled with intolerably slow handwriting rendering squid had the features that i needed and worked fine at high resolution i have used squid as my handwriting program for several months and i have grown to like it quite a bit over time there are many improvements i could suggest but nothing i suggest would matter over what it already does and does well

Text:
I love this app, I use it for all my highschool notes. It is by far the 
best writing experience on an android tablet that I have seen. But there 
are two things I would love to see done better. First I would love it to 
have more options with notebooks, maybe having the option to create 
multiple notebooks within notebook. I also feel the tools could have more 
customization, for instance, what if I want the square template but also 
want the pen opacity to be down? It would also be nice to store different 
pens that I use, I like taking my main notes in black and then adding Sub 
notes in pink but also with a smaller pen width, I don't want to have to 
toggle both of those when trying to change pens, especially during class.it 
would be nice to all my favourite pen set ups just a click away.

Text:
Great app, I use this on a Samsung Galaxy tablet with an s-pen. It's my go 
to app for note taking. The infinite page option is great for diagram 
sketching and then pen sensitivity and tracking accuracy beats the built in 
S Note app for my purposes. Being able to zoom in and annotate in fine 
detail is a great feature, as is the high quality export. The only areas 
where the Samsung app wins out are in more advanced page indexing 
facilities, and built in sound recording. Plenty of app store options for 
audio recording though. Highly recommend if you use your phone or tablet as 
a productivity tool.
text: great app i use this on a samsung galaxy tablet with an spen its my go to app for note taking the infinite page option is great for diagram sketching and then pen sensitivity and tracking accuracy beats the built in s note app for my purposes being able to zoom in and annotate in fine detail is a great feature as is the high quality export the only areas where the samsung app wins out are in more advanced page indexing facilities and built in sound recording plenty of app store options for audio recording though highly recommend if you use your phone or tablet as a productivity tool

Text:
As a math professor, I downloaded this app as a way to workout homeork 
problems for my students, and to take notes during meetings. This was an 
okay app until I upgraded to premium. It now allows me to take my quizzes, 
tests, class notes, power points, pdf, etc, open them in squid, then write 
over them. Couple this with a screen recording app, and I hope to greatly 
expand my reach as an educator (woe be unto my students). Also, couple this 
with a document scaning app, and now you can scan/import meeting handouts, 
add notes/write over them, and squid will save it as 1 file. It is a great 
way to actually digitize meeting notes and keep your office from getting 
over cluttered with handouts. As a note taking app, the writing reconition 
is very good (just set your s pen button to the eraser); however, I have 
not tried out using pressure sensitivity to adjust writing thickness.
text: as a math professor i downloaded this app as a way to workout homeork problems for my students and to take notes during meetings this was an okay app until i upgraded to premium it now allows me to take my quizzes tests class notes power points pdf etc open them in squid then write over them couple this with a screen recording app and i hope to greatly expand my reach as an educator woe be unto my students also couple this with a document scaning app and now you can scanimport meeting handouts add noteswrite over them and squid will save it as file it is a great way to actually digitize meeting notes and keep your office from getting over cluttered with handouts as a note taking app the writing reconition is very good just set your s pen button to the eraser however i have not tried out using pressure sensitivity to adjust writing thickness

when this comes to Android.

Text:
I use this app for taking notes on my lecture slides. The problem that I 
keep having is with slides that have a lot of pictures on them. I end up 
having to wait a long time for those pages to lead, which makes me miss 
some of the notes I want to take down. This is very important to me as 
university classes are very fast paced and profs don't wait for anyone. One 
suggestion would be to have the option to flatten the document as you 
import it onto the app. I personally don't care to have my pages be 
flattened, as I won't be needing to export text or images from my pdfs. I 
understand that some people might still need their content to be separable, 
so I think adding the option to flatten your pdf is better than making it 
the default. Please address this issue this app is extremely helpful 
otherwise.

Text: Supports amazing features such as using only the stylus for input combined with using your finger as an eraser. The lasso tool is a winner, better than OneNote's, with it you can change the color and the width of previously made pencil marks. It has a wide array of paper templates, color picker. Its fantastic. Also, you can change the size of the paper, facilitating export/printing, something in which OneNote has greatly failed me before. There is PDF import/export, and editing. 4*only because the writing is pretty clunky, needs smoothing, and there is only one kind of pen. Also, I would like to see notebook subdivisions! Premium subscription is totally worth (10/yr approx 0.83¢/month, Bargain!)

Text: On my Samsung Galaxy Note 4, which has a resolution of 2560x1440 and a Super AMOLED display, I use the "Squid - Take Notes & Markup PDFs" writing app from the Google play store. And I must say, the writing experience is the closest thing to actually using pencil/pen on paper of a number of popular apps I tested; even better then Samsung's own S Note. The Squid app, which used to be called Papyrus, has near zero latency when writing or drawing. And when comparing Squid to other apps such as Autodesk SketchBook and Wacom's Bamboo Paper on my Note 4, Squid wins hands down. The latency in the other apps is very noticeable, when coming from a Squid writing/drawing session. I use a Staedtler Noris Digital Samsung Pencil, which is sold on Amazon for $19.99.

Text: I recently got a Samsung Chromebook Pro for school, and I absolutely LOVE taking notes with this app.  I can have separate notebooks for all my different classes, I can use their infinite pages to fit an entire lecture's notes on a single page, making it really easy to find the notes from a specific day.  I'm pretty sure my classmates are all really grateful that I can easily turn my notes into a pdf that I can email to them too.  Lots of customization in how the pen works (I've found that 0.3 without pressure sensitivity works best for me).  I love the zoom feature.  It's really nice when you want to write small notes about something but you don't want to take up a whole line. I paid the few extra bucks for the "premium" upgrade, which if I remember correctly included the highlighter option, which is quite nice as well.  The premium package also has a bunch of other page templates like graph paper and stuff which I'll probably never use, but I'm sure would be super handy for someone else.  Honestly, I think my only complaints is that the highlighter doesn't look right... but that could just be that I haven't played around with the settings enough.  I've also had a couple crashes, but I've never lost anything and it's pretty rare and doesn't even take long to restart the app. I definitely recommend this app if you have a tablet with a stylus.  EDIT:  I can't believe I forgot to mention my absolute favorite feature!  THE UNDO BUTTON! I use it so often that I've actually found myself reaching for it when I make a mistake on actual paper!  The eraser is really nice too because it can get rid of an entire penstroke at once (though you can swap so that it only erases what you want too).  And I use the lasso tool a ton when I want to move things around, or copy and paste diagrams and stuff.  Honestly, I love how clean I can make my notes with this app (and how easy it is to do so)!
text: i recently got a samsung chromebook pro for school and i absolutely love taking notes with this app i can have separate notebooks for all my different classes i can use their infinite pages to fit an entire lectures notes on a single page making it really easy to find the notes from a specific day im pretty sure my classmates are all really grateful that i can easily turn my notes into a pdf that i can email to them too lots of customization in how the pen works ive found that without pressure sensitivity works best for me i love the zoom feature its really nice when you want to write small notes about something but you dont want to take up a whole line i paid the few extra bucks for the premium upgrade which if i remember correctly included the highlighter option which is quite nice as well the premium package also has a bunch of other page templates like graph paper and stuff which ill probably never use but im sure would be super handy for someone else honestly i think my only complaints is that the highlighter doesnt look right but that could just be that i havent played around with the settings enough ive also had a couple crashes but ive never lost anything and its pretty rare and doesnt even take long to restart the app i definitely recommend this app if you have a tablet with a stylus edit i cant believe i forgot to mention my absolute favorite feature the undo button i use it so often that ive actually found myself reaching for it when i make a mistake on actual paper the eraser is really nice too because it can get rid of an entire penstroke at once though you can swap so that it only erases what you want too and i use the lasso tool a ton when i want to move things around or copy and paste diagrams and stuff honestly i love how clean i can make my notes with this app and how easy it is to do so

Text: As far as operational smoothness goes, it is phenomenal. I give it 5 stars cuz it's truly done well. Im grateful for the effort put into it. The zoom u can do and the ease of use is awesome. HOWEVER, developers, it's been a very long time already since u first came out, it's time u add these feature already: Please, augment the pen selection - now there is only 1 pen style. Most every other similar app has that. The color match feature is so critical that you're missing. The writing needs to be smoother as well. Right now it is very choppy, perhaps because it is vector based. Also, subfolder/directory ability, to be able to organize better.   02/14/18  Update I think it's time you integrate these critical things I've asked for for months. We're paying for this app you know, and I can't remember when you had the last meaningful upgraded. I still think it's a great app but next time I write a review I'm am going to give this app a 2-star rating and will definitely stop paying for it if there is no improvement as there are other apps out there now compete very well with this

Text: Downloaded 10 or so note taking apps for my Note 8. This is the cream of the crop. I've opted to pay the $1 monthly to improve things even more and to support the app and hopefully it'll get even better! There are a bunch of options for backgrounds and pens, and highlighters. I also like how the notes are saved and accessed. It's easy to organize everything.  When on phone calls that I need to take note of the date auto populates and I can place on speaker and open a note and jot down everything I need.  Truly enjoy this app, it's my most used. It's also one I recommend if anyone sees me using it.

Text: I paid for this app. Its working beautiful with my Samsung TAB S3.  Features i like most in this app are: 1. Best palm rejection with saperate pen and finger mode. 2. All variety of colors are available. 3. Simple app environment. 4. Most important pattern of pages  are available.(after purchase) 5. Fix zoom with adjustable ratio. (most helpful)  After using this app, i think these features make its even more better: 1. Color fill tool within closed boundaries. 2. More shapes like. ( hexagon, Pentagon, all direction arrow) 3. Table feature with column and row. 4. Add video file with supportive extension. (it can make notes more alive)  Finding some bugs like: 1. When i do zoom in, i could not write on exact location, mean that if i try to write after zoom in, stroke is delievered at different place.  2. Every time zoom in and out working with slight delay which is annoying.  Overall experience is best. Thank you Squid. 😀
text: i paid for this app its working beautiful with my samsung tab s features i like most in this app are best palm rejection with saperate pen and finger mode all variety of colors are available simple app environment most important pattern of pages are availableafter purchase fix zoom with adjustable ratio most helpful after using this app i think these features make its even more better color fill tool within closed boundaries more shapes like hexagon pentagon all direction arrow table feature with column and row add video file with supportive extension it can make notes more alive finding some bugs like when i do zoom in i could not write on exact location mean that if i try to write after zoom in stroke is delievered at different place every time zoom in and out working with slight delay which is annoying overall experience is best thank you squid

Text: I liked trying this app out a lot. It worked very well with my Samsung Chromebook Pro as an Android app. My handwriting wasn't what I hoped it would be, and I struggle with the keyboard on the back of the Pro, but I think it would improve with use of the app. Unfortunately, the author wants a monthly ongoing fee for the app, or you use the "basic" edition. This would be a great $4 or even $5 app - but they want $1/mo or $10/year. In its basic form, there are other great apps that do as well, if not better, and are also free. The free version is fine, but again, so are others that have features this one charges for. (You can pay to upgrade individual add ons like PDF import and eraser tools, but that is more than the app is worth.)

Text: This is almost a great app with a few frustrating flaws. First, its really great to have an app that allows you to draw and "paint" right over PDF's. I use this for marking up landscape drawings with edits for the drafting team. I also use it for responding to questions from contractors. In this, it works well - it's very well synced with dropbox, Google Drive, and any other way you like to share. A few simple problems, however, are VERY frustrating. 1. From my experience and research, you cannot erase part of highlighted areas (which I used frequently). It is an all or nothing delete. 2.  With no confirmation for closing a file, I sometimes bump the back button and the file closes. Auto saving keeps me from losing the file, but I also lose the option for undoing. Not huge, but definitely frustrating. Add a confirmation screen for exiting and the problem is gone. More to come...

Text: This is quite possibly the best "note-taking" app I've ever used.. but it's so much more than that.   It's a very powerful vector drawing tool, with an extremely simple but powerful interface. If you have some text you've hand-written, you can then go and select parts of it, then change the size, or the color, or the brush stroke thickness, or even duplicate it several times then slightly modify each one, rather than having to write something from scratch several times.   And since it's vector-based rather than rasterised, there's no quality loss to writing/drawing something at one size, and then later resizing it, or dragging it around the place, etc. <3  Basically, it's a really fantastic app. I'm very happy that I stumbled upon it however many years ago when I first got a tablet with a built-in stylus, and it has served me well ever since.    Probably the one feature that it's """missing""" (and I say that in the sense that I have absolutely no expectation of it being a feature) would be being able to choose custom typefaces / write with a monospaced font (and beyond that, being able to write syntax-highlighted code....) -- it's a very specific use-case :)
text: this is quite possibly the best notetaking app ive ever used but its so much more than that its a very powerful vector drawing tool with an extremely simple but powerful interface if you have some text youve handwritten you can then go and select parts of it then change the size or the color or the brush stroke thickness or even duplicate it several times then slightly modify each one rather than having to write something from scratch several times and since its vectorbased rather than rasterised theres no quality loss to writingdrawing something at one size and then later resizing it or dragging it around the place etc basically its a really fantastic app im very happy that i stumbled upon it however many years ago when i first got a tablet with a builtin stylus and it has served me well ever since probably the one feature that its missing and i say that in the sense that i have absolutely no expectation of it being a feature would be being able to choose custom typefaces write with a monospaced font and beyond that being able to write syntaxhighlighted code its a very specific usecase

The first feature would be to have folders within the note books. For example have a circuits note book and some folders in there, one for class notes, one for homework, and one for practice. This would greatly enhance the app and would definitely make it 5/5.  Another feature that I would love to see is to have a "night mode" where the background is black and the lines in the paper white so it's easier to write and not shed too much light in the room if it's during a presentation with the lights turned off.  Another feature I would love to see would be top add different backgrounds. Finally I would love to have the option to add pages in a pdf, not just at the end but between pages so I can take more explicit notes.  All this features would make this app be on top for a long time.  However, even without them this app is amazing.
text: i love this app because im always taking notes during class or doing homework and it works great with the s pen however i would like some features added the first feature would be to have folders within the note books for example have a circuits note book and some folders in there one for class notes one for homework and one for practice this would greatly enhance the app and would definitely make it another feature that i would love to see is to have a night mode where the background is black and the lines in the paper white so its easier to write and not shed too much light in the room if its during a presentation with the lights turned off another feature i would love to see would be top add different backgrounds finally i would love to have the option to add pages in a pdf not just at the end but between pages so i can take more explicit notes all this features would make this app be on top for a long time however even without them this app is amazing

Text: I would give squid 5 stars because it  does serve as an incredible platform to use handwriting on touchscreen devices. However this app could use some minor tweeks to make it comparable to platforms like evernote.  If the creators of squid do not intend to make this app to wholesome, by updating the app to add features such as typing word documents and organizational tools like sub-folders. Squid should expect that users will want to  combine their notes with the other material on a platform that provides these details. The app does allow for exporting or backing up documents using drop-box or box, but there is no easy way to quickly upload to other platforms like onedrive or the google cloud.   This app is great if you're just trying to jot down some stuff on a touchscreen device. However if you intend to use it as your primary tool for school or work, the app needs some help before it can provide as a good platform for all of your work.

Text: I installed Squid on my Chromebook Plus and it's by far the best note taking software that I have used on this device. It behaves just like writing with pen and paper. Installing Squid on my phone is just as great but the Chromebook's pen is far more fun to use than my finger or stylus. Squid, an Android app running under Chrome OS, is marvelous and adapts to the large screen like a native app. I recommend!!

Text: I recently switched to squid for my work notes, because of its ability to work offline, edit pdfs, save directly to my phone (note 4), work with my stylus, and locally backup notes.  I've used a number of the more popular notetaking apps for work or personal notes, and so far am pleased with squid's capabilities.  I think it is definitely a developing app, with a lot of room for improvement, but most people would find it useful and user friendly.  A couple freatures I would like to see is the ability to have notebooks within notebooks (for better note storage) and a close-up mode similar to snote or inkredible (I like taking notes on letter sized paper, which is a little frustrating with this app.  The infinite page works well though).  Would definitely recommend giving it a try!
text: i recently switched to squid for my work notes because of its ability to work offline edit pdfs save directly to my phone note work with my stylus and locally backup notes ive used a number of the more popular notetaking apps for work or personal notes and so far am pleased with squids capabilities i think it is definitely a developing app with a lot of room for improvement but most people would find it useful and user friendly a couple freatures i would like to see is the ability to have notebooks within notebooks for better note storage and a closeup mode similar to snote or inkredible i like taking notes on letter sized paper which is a little frustrating with this app the infinite page works well though would definitely recommend giving it a try

Text: Paid user here. This app has so much potential and is so useful, but it is hurt by a few key problems. If the following could be fixed, it would be one of the best apps on the Play Store:  1 - Please add continuous scroll for PDFs, like in Adobe Reader / Foxit.  2 - If you add continuous scroll, please allow PDFs to still be editable in continuous scroll! 3 - Please allow default widths to be applicable to imported pdfs, whether in portrait or landscape; it's a huge pain to have to continuously zoom in or out for every page of a document I'm reading / scrolling through.  4 - Please enable full screen with no toolbar up top; maybe a single finger tap could call up or hide the toolbar, like in many other apps? 5 - please enable inverted dark theme for text / white background! For example, if I'm reading and annotating a screenplay, especially at night or on an AMOLED display, it would be great to be able to make the white PDF background black.   I've been hopping between Squid and Adobe Reader on my tablet because both apps do half of what I need. If squid could add the above, it would be great and I would keep paying for it.
text: paid user here this app has so much potential and is so useful but it is hurt by a few key problems if the following could be fixed it would be one of the best apps on the play store please add continuous scroll for pdfs like in adobe reader foxit if you add continuous scroll please allow pdfs to still be editable in continuous scroll please allow default widths to be applicable to imported pdfs whether in portrait or landscape its a huge pain to have to continuously zoom in or out for every page of a document im reading scrolling through please enable full screen with no toolbar up top maybe a single finger tap could call up or hide the toolbar like in many other apps please enable inverted dark theme for text white background for example if im reading and annotating a screenplay especially at night or on an amoled display it would be great to be able to make the white pdf background black ive been hopping between squid and adobe reader on my tablet because both apps do half of what i need if squid could add the above it would be great and i would keep paying for it

Text: Best note taking app that supports the active pen. Premium purchases are worth it. Much easier to use then LectureNotes, but not as customizable. There is no latency in regards to pen input. The pen chooser is quick and intuitive, but there is room for improvement. I purchased all the premium features and among them my favorites are the highlighter and PDF import. Premium paper patterns are only available as a subscription service. The cloud backup (also premium) implements Dropbox or Box as the backup service, which works fairly well as a backup tool. However, I would like a cloud sync feature (like Dropbox on the PC or like Google Drive) so that my notes automatically sync across devices. Right now, it works more like a backup service then a sync service even though it uses Dropbox. Your changes on one device will not sync to the other device, you have to do this manually by restoring from a backup and saving a backup.
text: best note taking app that supports the active pen premium purchases are worth it much easier to use then lecturenotes but not as customizable there is no latency in regards to pen input the pen chooser is quick and intuitive but there is room for improvement i purchased all the premium features and among them my favorites are the highlighter and pdf import premium paper patterns are only available as a subscription service the cloud backup also premium implements dropbox or box as the backup service which works fairly well as a backup tool however i would like a cloud sync feature like dropbox on the pc or like google drive so that my notes automatically sync across devices right now it works more like a backup service then a sync service even though it uses dropbox your changes on one device will not sync to the other device you have to do this manually by restoring from a backup and saving a backup

It would also be nice to be able to draw a circle with constraints (so that it is 100% circular) and from centre. I use Squid for technical DIY concept drawings and features I mention would make the app a lot better for this purpose. Selection is also imprecise at times - it's really hard to select a line even when you zoom in very close - several taps are necessary. Oh and automatic synchronization/backup across multiple devices is badly needed.

Text: I use my tablet for note taking for university and used it during a levels. In the past I gave this app a 5 star review saying all it needed was a writing input zone (something I know many many other users would agree with). I am extremely disappointed to see it still hasn't been added as a feature, especially as users have been requesting it for such a long time. It would make writing in this app much much much easier. Something like what lecture notes and notability have in this regards would go a long way. Also having endless scrolling for your pages (again like lecture notes and notability) rather than having to press between pages would be nice as well as it would be quicker to check past lines of works when doing long equations and such. Add these two features (preferably as one time pay features seeing as they feel like key features to every other good writing app) and this review would instantly be changed to five stars.

Text: I'm rating it a 4 so hopefully the devs are more likely to see my suggestions. If anybody finds this to be in bad taste, I will change it to a 5 star to reflect my actual opinion of the app. First a quick review. This app is fantastic. I use it for taking notes in university. I use it to jot down video game ideas. I use it to doodle when I'm not paying attention to a lecture.  The free version is everything you need to take sufficient notes although I've payed for a few tools to enhance the experience; well worth it. If i had ONE wish, it would be that notes would have tags and be searchable by the tags so that we could search for notes by the content. Titles just aren't enough for me to remember everything the notes contain.   Adding compatibility with multi-window on galaxy tablets would be awesome too so that I could read a pdf textbook and take notes simultaneously. Anyway, thanks for saving me from wasting paper and pencils and erasers. Keep up the good work.

Text: I have used S-note, Evernote and OneNote. This app is better than all of them.   Key features are: endless scrolling, many different line and grid options, unlimited color selections. This would make color coding notes easier. A more robust text tool would be nice too.

Text: I actually love squid. I'm only giving it a 3 because of a couple issues. First, it crashes often and you can lose some of your work. In fact the last couple times it crashed , it then immediately asked me to rate it. Ironic? Second , it can't sync. So if you have it on your phone and your tablet you can't update notes across the two. It does have a backup function to Dropbox which is at least some comfort. Third , I wish it integrated better with Windows so I could edit and better work with my notes from my laptop. Otherwise , it's simple and personal. I originally looked at lecture notes , but it was way too complicated for what I was looking for. For simple handwriting notes and PDFs. It's great. I highly recommend it to corporate trainers , because you can put all your lesson materials in it and you don't have to lug around a big program binder.

Text: Great little app & helpful / communicative developer.  Been using the Premium (though NON subscription) version of this app for about 8 months now.  It's generally been great!  The only things that have been a little tedious is that the Cloud based sync using Box can be a little on the slow side when you have an increasing number of files .   Also when you have a large ongoing ("infinity") sized document, strolling can be a little on the slower side as the document when fully sized & takes a few moments to get reconfigured / repopulate with each swipe. With the kind of docs I create, that can delay things when editing & looking for a section.  Some people have expressed concern about the subscription model being 'enforced' on them. Personally I don't have a problem with developers going subscription & would have upgraded to it if it offered more features than simply a few paper styles that I didn't really have a need for or if I didn't already purchase all the Premium add ons.  But as I purchased all the Premium add ons separately last year (which I believe is / was still an option now ), I didn't yet see the value in going subscription. Time will tell if this changes.
text: great little app helpful communicative developer been using the premium though non subscription version of this app for about months now its generally been great the only things that have been a little tedious is that the cloud based sync using box can be a little on the slow side when you have an increasing number of files also when you have a large ongoing infinity sized document strolling can be a little on the slower side as the document when fully sized takes a few moments to get reconfigured repopulate with each swipe with the kind of docs i create that can delay things when editing looking for a section some people have expressed concern about the subscription model being enforced on them personally i dont have a problem with developers going subscription would have upgraded to it if it offered more features than simply a few paper styles that i didnt really have a need for or if i didnt already purchase all the premium add ons but as i purchased all the premium add ons separately last year which i believe is was still an option now i didnt yet see the value in going subscription time will tell if this changes

Text: I have been using Squid/Papyrus for a few years, and I highly recommend it!   What makes it better than the other handwriting apps is, that you can use the Stylus pen for writing and erase written text by touching the screen with the finger, so there is no need to switch between the pen/eraser mode.  Features I would love to see in the future would be a search mode based on handwriting recognition, and a way to sync notes between different devices.  Thank you for the great app!

Text: I uninstalled and reinstalled squid and found that all of my notes are gone! No Warning on uninstall that all of my notes would be erased. Is this really true? On is there away to recover my notes?... I was finally able to restore my subscription after losing all paid features for several months. It turns out that Squid could not tell that I was the main software user. It thought that my son's account was the main software user. Not clear on how it got confused. Never the less, after removing my son's account from my tablet, and after uninstalling and reinstalling the software, I was able to use paid for features. But the final burn... After restoring my notes from cloud backup, I lost all of my notes from since 5-Dec of last year. It seems that Squid broke my backups during the move from what it was formaly, "Papyrus". Although I love the features, given the huge loss of data... I give only 1 star. I wish better luck for others.
text: i uninstalled and reinstalled squid and found that all of my notes are gone no warning on uninstall that all of my notes would be erased is this really true on is there away to recover my notes i was finally able to restore my subscription after losing all paid features for several months it turns out that squid could not tell that i was the main software user it thought that my sons account was the main software user not clear on how it got confused never the less after removing my sons account from my tablet and after uninstalling and reinstalling the software i was able to use paid for features but the final burn after restoring my notes from cloud backup i lost all of my notes from since dec of last year it seems that squid broke my backups during the move from what it was formaly papyrus although i love the features given the huge loss of data i give only star i wish better luck for others

Text: Subscription-based apps appears too tempting to many developers, both individual and corporations.  I do not have a problem with apps being either--except for when an app is changed from paid features to subscription.  Regardless of how it may be presented, it is no less than an underhanded move by the developer.  If developers were to be fair, the previously purchases app would NOT be 'transformed' into subscription a based Frankenstein, but instead, presented SEPARATELY, as a new app.  Doing otherwise is simply vile.

Text: Edit (Apr 2016): I don't think I'd be rating this app this high if I hadn't been able to outright purchase the features, and had to rely on the subscription. It's everything i could ask for. The online forums are a good tool to provide feedback and it's nice to see where the developers plan on taking things. I'd love to see the ability to reorder pages in the future, but from what i can gather that is already in the works. Would also love the ability to backup to Google Drive instead of dropbox, and select tools straight from the ribbon instead of having to go into a dropdown list. Great job, love this app!

Text: UPDATE: Since upgrading my tablet, I have had zero problems with this app. Using it to take notes in class has made it possible for me to succeed in college.  I really liked the idea of being able to write with my finger on a tablet, as I have a condition that makes gripping a pencil very difficult. However, Papyrus randomly closes the note I'm working on and returns to the home screen without saving my work. I lose work, sometimes a lot. An auto-save feature would be nice, so the note would save itself every certain number of minutes. They should fix this random closing issue. It's making me want to find another notetaking program.  Also, when .pdfs are exported, small objects like periods get lost in the process. When working on math problems, decimals are always omitted during .pdf export.

Text: Great app for notetaking, especially for college students like myself. You can easily draw diagrams, import pictures and highlight important points. For me it was really useful for drawing chemical structures and writing eauations easily during class. You can export them to the cloud and have them anywhere. Never again will you carry around a backpack with 5 spiral notebooks in it, all you have to carry is a tablet with this app. One of the latest updates let you set a default page style, which is something I've wanted for a while (I'm fond of graph paper and the default before the update was notebook). Overall, great!

Text: Love the app! I've used notability before switching over to android and as far as I'm aware, this app is the closest to being as great if not better than notability. Update: The app is wonderful, but a few hundred notes later and the choice to backup my files to a drive is significantly harder to do. It takes ages for the files to upload and now it gives up halfway. Love the app and all, but there isn't a need to re-upload files that havent been changed. It would be better to upload the ones that have to save time.

Text: I purchased Squid long before the name change. It's pretty good for a "toy" app, but nowhere near as capable as Lecture Notes. No problem... I like to support independent developers, and thought the app had potential. But now the developers have gotten greedy, and have moved to a subscription model (for both new and existing customers)  to lock you into paying their living expenses from year to year. In fact they've posted a long article online trying to rationalize their feeling of entitlement... It reminds me of McDonalds workers who complain that they can't raise a family on the salary they're being paid.  Save yourself the coin and frustration and just buy Lecture Notes. It's a much more polished app, is extremely mature and reliable, and they understand what their product's worth! Buy it once and use it forever, including updates. None of this subscription crap!

Text: Update: working with Devs on PDF import.  Likely limited to PDFs created with a specific program.  If that and the cloud backup feature are solved, I would give 5 stars.  Used to love it.  But the premium features that I paid for no longer work.  The cloud backup service stopped working over a year ago.  The automated response from the devs is "We're very busy, but thanks for writing".  I've gotten two regarding this issue.  Then, the pdf import - the best part of the program - stopped working and hasn't worked for weeks now.  I got another automated response stating how overworked their devs are.  Granted I've only spend $8 on these features, they now render all my previous work with this program moot as the replacement program I must now find will be incompatible with my history.  Try the program for free, but I wouldn't pay for any of the added features.

Text: I've used many note taking apps and Squid is up there with the best. The feature that Squid has that no other note app has is the most amazing pressure sensitive writing! It blows many art apps out of the water. A joy to use. As a note app it falls in with S Note, Bamboo and Keep except that I wish Squid had Keep's reminders and maybe a brush and shader from Bamboo. Reminders though are the main missing thing for me (except sync between mobile and desktop version.) You can star notes and categorize them, import photos, mark up pdfs. I wish more features came free but at least the purchases are one-time. This app is also awesome on a Surface.

Text: Fantastic app.  I was disappointed to see the removal of the former app Papyrus but the features of the revised app are definite improvements.  A must for any Samsung Note device.  PDF support is a great addition.  The option to turn on/off the pressure sensitivity for Samsung S-Pen is helpful if you find the pressure sensitivity of the Note 5 an issue.  I was able to take a few pictures of products on my Note 5, bring the pictures into a note then draw a few comments on the pictures and type / write some additional comments, PDF the entire note and email (or text it) to a few people.  It may not have the organizational abilities of OneNote or Evernote, but it writes smoothly on Note devices and you can incorporate pictures and PDFs into an endless paper where you cannot do this as easily in other apps.
text: fantastic app i was disappointed to see the removal of the former app papyrus but the features of the revised app are definite improvements a must for any samsung note device pdf support is a great addition the option to turn onoff the pressure sensitivity for samsung spen is helpful if you find the pressure sensitivity of the note an issue i was able to take a few pictures of products on my note bring the pictures into a note then draw a few comments on the pictures and type write some additional comments pdf the entire note and email or text it to a few people it may not have the organizational abilities of onenote or evernote but it writes smoothly on note devices and you can incorporate pictures and pdfs into an endless paper where you cannot do this as easily in other apps
