Text: Update 12/15/2015: Since I use this for work, a functioning backup is critical. Unfortunately, the automatic backup and pdf functions ("premium" features for which I have paid) no longer work once you have accumulated a decent number of notes. Several fixes to this problem have been suggested by users on the Squid feedback website - such as incremental backups - but there is no indication of a plan to implement any solution.  So, if you just want to use it for a few doodles, it's great. But if you actually want something that you can count on, look somewhere else until they fix this issue.   Original: Still needs a few features to be added, but they seem to be pretty responsive to user input - so I expect to see those things implemented eventually.

Text: As far as features, it's as straightforward as an actual paper notebook. Open the app, create a notebook, and start writing smoothly and quickly. Erasing, and changing pen color on the fly is neat, as well as the ability to choose stationary (blank, college ruled, wide ruled, etc) per your preference. It truly is an electronic notepad.   Though, it slightly falls short of the accuracy found in apps like Evernote or Handrite Note, lacking the ability to compensate for stroke imperfections to keep what you write looking as close to your actual handwriting as possible. This irks me, but it probably won't bother most.

Text: I absolutely love this app on my Note10.1(2014).  I'm half way through my Electrical Engineering degree, and I take all of my notes on this app, and then export them for the rest of the class to use.  Feature Requests: 1) Google Drive integration.   - I maintain all of my class documents through Google Drive, and right now I have to manually export each note to drive.  Along that same theme....  2) Export Notebooks/Batch export - as it is right now I have to open the note, open the menu and export for every single note.  I really wish I could long press on a note/notes and export, as well as being able to long press on a notebook title and export.  3) Sub-notebook/folder organization -as I said, I use this for all my classes, which means I have a notebook for each class, but I've subdivided them further into notes folders for each class, homework folders for each class, as well as personal projects, to do lists, grocery list, sketches, etc....  I really really really need subfolders or a filebrowser and just have them organized on my flashcard/google drive.  4) Quick symbol drop down 5)LaTeX interpreter/math drop down menu.  would pay for plugin

Text: I have tried several handwritting note apps, and Squid ((formerly Papyrus) is the best out of the bunch.   I like Squid better then the in-built S-Note. (If you are using Note 8, you can download the improve S-Note).   Other handwritting Apps each have their strenghts and weaknesses, but for me Squid  stands out from the best. I    hope they do improve the software. For instance, I like INKredible which wins out on the smoothness of its handwritting and the background template.       Wishlist:   1. Page template e.,g. Diary Template (similar to INKredible)  2. Ability to copy from Samsung clipboard (ie. to select from web site and paste)  3. Smooth handwritting  4. Tool Pallette easily available rather then going into a sub-menu. 5. I choose the A4 papersize. However, when you zoom-in-out. It changes  your choose papersize from A4 to infinite, which is very naughty. 6. I can't insert a page before page one. 8. Everything I add a new page, I have to keep changing the page setting e.g. size to A4 and blank page. Why can't it default to what I want?. 9. Add image, give you lots of ways to add an image, but wish there was a dedicated 'add image from camera'.

Text: This app is a minimalist alternative to apps like Evernote or OneNote. Sometimes you just want to write something down quickly without navigating through multiple screens, logging into an account or generating a unique format document like a checklist. Squid is perfect when you need paper and don't have any but you have your smart phone. Its interface is sexy and highly intuitive. I've been looking for something like this for a while. Papyrus came close but it wasn't as sleek and the pages were hard to keep sized correctly. This redesign, complete with the coolest logo ever, make me smile. I hope Squid doesn't try to compete with other note apps by adding more and more distracting features over time. This app is worth way more than it's premium package price in its current state.
text: this app is a minimalist alternative to apps like evernote or onenote sometimes you just want to write something down quickly without navigating through multiple screens logging into an account or generating a unique format document like a checklist squid is perfect when you need paper and dont have any but you have your smart phone its interface is sexy and highly intuitive ive been looking for something like this for a while papyrus came close but it wasnt as sleek and the pages were hard to keep sized correctly this redesign complete with the coolest logo ever make me smile i hope squid doesnt try to compete with other note apps by adding more and more distracting features over time this app is worth way more than its premium package price in its current state

Text: The basic work flow is great. It's simple and quick to use and I would recommend it especially for anyone with a galaxy note device. There are just a couple of things I wish it had. 1. You should be able to set a default page layout for each notebook. Just as an example, I like the graph paper for math but lined for other things. 2. At the end I suggest this app. to all the Galaxy note users!

Text: Background: I came from IOS on an ipad mini and iphone, this app replaced Notability... Almost.   The Good: Drawing features are excellent. Love the touch sensitivity built into the stylus of the note. Differentiating stylus input from finger input is so great. I can draw with the stylus, and if needed, zoom in with my fingers, draw a marquee around an object it with my finger to select it, and then scale, copy, move or delete with no tool chagning. I bought all the add-on's after the free trial period without even hesitating. They're all  extremely useful. Although, to be fair, a little expensive. In most cases, it's easy to manipulate images from other apps through sharing and/or opening into squid/papyrus.    The Bad: Editing text... aweful. Some bugginess on the widgets loosing their names in a folder for shortcuts and infinite screen size creates issues where the screen stops recognizing finger inputs at the system level, not application level. The backup features NEEDS to be able to use the same file on multiple devices.   I would replace this with notibility if I could for the improved text, backup, and cloud features.
text: background i came from ios on an ipad mini and iphone this app replaced notability almost the good drawing features are excellent love the touch sensitivity built into the stylus of the note differentiating stylus input from finger input is so great i can draw with the stylus and if needed zoom in with my fingers draw a marquee around an object it with my finger to select it and then scale copy move or delete with no tool chagning i bought all the addons after the free trial period without even hesitating theyre all extremely useful although to be fair a little expensive in most cases its easy to manipulate images from other apps through sharing andor opening into squidpapyrus the bad editing text aweful some bugginess on the widgets loosing their names in a folder for shortcuts and infinite screen size creates issues where the screen stops recognizing finger inputs at the system level not application level the backup features needs to be able to use the same file on multiple devices i would replace this with notibility if i could for the improved text backup and cloud features

Text: I'm using a Samsung Note Pro 12.2, rooted and on CyanogenMod 12.1.  Didn't like the limitations of KNOX, TouchWiz, and regular Android.  This meant losing a good program, though - Samsung's S-Note.  There are apps that make up for that, and Squid is the key part.  Excellent ink, good use of cloud, even better use of local storage (the main reason I flashed CM12.1).  I am a presenter/teacher and love being able to show Squid notes and drawing via Chromecast - a wonderful combination.  I don't use the PDF import (yet - thinking about it), but love the premium tool pack.

Text: This is a great app that works like a charm. I use it to keep charts to manage my diabetes, for notes at client locations and for lists. I have two of the three paid plugins and wow, they are great.  The thing is, there is no way to duplicate documents. In other words, no Save As feature, and this is a killer. I do hope they add it soon. Another thing that is really needed is access to the same docs over multiple devices. I understand this second feature is a lot to ask for, but sometimes I have one device but not the other and not being able to get at my stuff harshes my app buzz. I will definitely recommend this to others. If you have a tablet with a pen, this is the app you've been waiting for.

Text: --- If you write with the page fitted to the screen (very small zoom) it does not detect as many points as other apps do (write, snote, inkredible...) leaving a very wobbly difficult to read text. If I want the strokes to be straight you need to zoom a lot in everything you write. +++ The best and quickest pdf import / export by far with any other app in the market. + Good sincronisation with dropbox - 2 clicks to change tools even ifi have plenty of space in my screen - Can't save predifined pens. -- You can't rotate your strokes. - It would be nice to be able to share an image with the app to add it to a note / current note. - The pressure of my spen also creates a wobbly behaviour in most of the starting and endings of my strokes. - The highlighter could be implemented in a way that doesn't paint over the black text (just paint the background) - A little bit more of personalization would be welcomed (maybe an advanced menu to keep it simple for newbies)

Text: After trying lots of apps that combine PDF annotation and handwriting, Papyrus is my choice. Text: Premium offerings with hefty price tags. 4.99 for pdf import, 2.99 for more tools that the one pen you get already, and another 2.99 for cloud saving. Text: This app is really useful and has some great features that I have put to use while note-taking and studying. However, there is an issue with the responsiveness of the touchscreen that occurs intermittently on my tablet, where it will stop recognizing my finger when I try to erase strokes. I have dealt with this by turning off and back on the display, which will fix the problem for a while. I have also noticed that the S Pen will occasionally write things about a centimeter away from the point where the pen is applied on-screen. I'm not sure if these problems are due to my tablet or the application, but other than that, this app is highly recommendable.   One suggestion for future development could be to include a feature where automatic syncing to the cloud is done only to files that have been updated/ written on since the last synchronization (instead of uploading all files to the cloud each time).
text: this app is really useful and has some great features that i have put to use while notetaking and studying however there is an issue with the responsiveness of the touchscreen that occurs intermittently on my tablet where it will stop recognizing my finger when i try to erase strokes i have dealt with this by turning off and back on the display which will fix the problem for a while i have also noticed that the s pen will occasionally write things about a centimeter away from the point where the pen is applied onscreen im not sure if these problems are due to my tablet or the application but other than that this app is highly recommendable one suggestion for future development could be to include a feature where automatic syncing to the cloud is done only to files that have been updated written on since the last synchronization instead of uploading all files to the cloud each time

Text: Excellent app for note-taking and annotating pdf's.  In my view, two features would really make it stand out: First, it is odd that, when reading pdfs, the zoom settings change each time you turn a page. If I want "Fit width" on page 18, the setting should stay there on page 19.  Second, using two fingers allows you to move around a page, which is great. It would be even better, if you could swipe to the next page too, rather than having to press a button to do that.  Other than that, the app is really excellent. Adding these features would make it perfect, in my view.

Text: I use this to take notes on pdf slides using my Samsung Note 10.1 (2014).  Unlike S note, the pdf feature correctly imports all LaTeX math correctly (dropping minus signs and Greek letters at random is not acceptable!). I'm also very impressed with the handwriting -- it looks smooth and accurately reflects my paper-and-pencil handwriting. The Dropbox integration ensures I have access to all of my notes on every device. I tested several note-taking programs before choosing Papyrus and found I always missed the "finger swipe to erase" function.  I will happily pay for the pdf and Dropbox features when my free trial is over.  This app is excellent!

Text: This is my primary way of notetaking in my engineering college. I love it, especially with the cloud service and expandable tool pack. Couple suggestions: (1) I wish the tool picker were permanently expandable so I could switch tools with one tap instead of two or three. This would be very helpful for quick notetaking in lecture settings. (2) I also wish two finger double taps were customizable so that, instead of zooming, it could toggle between the pen and the eraser or something along those lines. Customization is good, but not yet at 100%, even with premium features.

Text: This is a nice, straightforward handwriting and drawing app that makes a solid complement to any stylus-focused tablet use.  The developers have done a great job of sensibly balancing free vs. premium features that can be purchased in-app without making this customer feel exploited.  And so, I would love to give this app a 5-star review if it weren't for one *very* glaring oversight: the lack of any ability to share into the Papyrus app itself from other apps.  Come on, devs, this is Android and the Share intent is part of app making 101 for the platform.  Fix this and I'll happily raise my score.

Text: This app works flawlessly with my Samsung Galaxy Note. However, I don't use this app for taking notes in school because it lacks the ability to automatically save notes to a PDF file (you can manually import a PDF, edit it, then export it as a PDF, but you can't use it to just open a PDF and save your edits the PDF file). If you're looking for an app that lets you take notes directly on a PDF, then sync the annotated PDF with your computer, check out the free Adobe Reader app. I will update this review if they add that functionality in a future release.
text: this app works flawlessly with my samsung galaxy note however i dont use this app for taking notes in school because it lacks the ability to automatically save notes to a pdf file you can manually import a pdf edit it then export it as a pdf but you cant use it to just open a pdf and save your edits the pdf file if youre looking for an app that lets you take notes directly on a pdf then sync the annotated pdf with your computer check out the free adobe reader app i will update this review if they add that functionality in a future release

Text: Anyone that gives this less than 5 stars is either uninformed or unreasonable. It's vector graphics - there are limitations which the app provides for. Sure there might be bugs but such is the nature of software. I have researched pen, handwriting, traditional tablet PCs, in grad school before touch screen devices were ubiquitous. This app addresses the limitations we had back then! It's downright amazing! Check out the folks at SBIM if you want to see how much difficult hard work went into this app. Props!

Text: Has a combo of features that are surprisingly difficult to find - highlight and take notes on the document, then save as the original document on my device so I don't have to go looking for it. What could be improved?  It needs an easier way to zoom the pages, like a default zoom level you can select for the document. Also, the default edit setting shouldn't be a writing tool. I should have to select when I want a screen press to write something. Default should be one-finger moves the page. It needs a quick page select feature at the bottom of the screen as well as a little indicator telling me I'm on page x of xx. Lastly, an intelligent highlight assist is needed - other apps sense the line of text and keep you on it, while Papyrus essentially has a draw function requiring impeccable accuracy to highlight.

Text: This app is simple yet powerful. The infinite page size (which I'm still almost infinitely less than using completely) let's me not stop mid thought to add a page or move text over. The lasso (copy/paste) tool is scarily good at moving only what I want (gets entire shapes/letters without bordering shapes/letters or cutting in half), and for resizing. I'm assuming it uses vectors but whatever it is makes resizing selections stay just as clear and sharp. And unlike other apps it doesn't have any pause between drawing and seeing it on the screen. I used lecture notes before this and loved it except for the speed (even using all the tweaks the author suggested). And I didn't know infinite page size was a possibility. The only thing I can think of wanting is more shapes, like an arrow. But that's easy to just draw and copy/paste.

Text: On the other hand the app is kind of cool, and fun, and probably good for data that's not actually critical.  This app lost me hundreds of dollars, and, except for my keenness of mind, could have ended in the death of myself. I used this app for mission-critical, real-time note-taking for medication and dosage management, since it was the only one with support for the stylus on the Note 3 and skeumorphic paper. The app glitched and deleted three days worth of notes (which are lists of numbers for me, including times and dosages), and replaced them with no warning with notes from three days ago. If I had trusted the app and not had the intuition that 'these numbers are wrong', harm could have resulted. LESSON: NEVER USE NON-CERTIFIED 'CONSUMER'-GRADE TRASH FOR MISSION-CRITICAL APPLICATIONS.  Negative ten, and the first review I have ever posted -- and ever intend to. I've never had an app that nearly let me die before. It's like a anaesthesia timer that counts two minutes per minute.

Text: I love this for basic note taking! I have talked numerous people into downloading it, and they all love it for notes. However I am very reluctant to shell out over $10.00 for the extras. I really don't know why there are three separate updates. I'm no business major but it seems logical that if you made a "pro" version, bundled all the updates into one, and cut it down in price to say...$1.99-$3.99 you would get a LOT more purchases, and in the long run... $$$   Or at least have a trial to where we can try out the updates so we know if it's worth all that money. Thanks for the basic part of it. Please consider all the ones who are begging for more affordable updates. Do that and it's 5 stars all the way. You're close, you're so close....                                                          Update!   11/29/14 I love how this had a sale on the upgrades. I purchased a couple of them when they did. The only one I haven't is cloud storage because I don't need it. Also they added a trial period which is great! I use this app all the time and couldn't be without it. And it helps that they keep updating it with more features.  I would love to see the option for "conversation boxes"

Text: This app basically has every feature I need/want for taking notes in my lectures, but it has one severe drawback: the writing is NOT smooth if you are not zoomed in enough. There are so many features that I LOVE about this app. It is easy to take pictures of slides, crop them and insert them into my notes. It's really easy to erase, zoom in and out, scroll. You can import PDFs and write your notes on them directly. The app is robust and easy to use, but my writing has all these squiggly lines at the beginning and end of my letters and I'm really, really tired of it. Papyrus is the best note taking app for lectures, but these squiggly lines have had me searching for a replacement for months.

Text: I bulk installed around 10 similar apps looking for something like this. Nothing offers such a well design app for note taking. This is the only one left installed. Operation is learnt in about 5 mins.  No nonsense design means you can open new or add to existing organised notes or notebooks with very few selections.  I'm using it in the context of an IT support department so I need to get going in the time it takes to pick the phone up and say 'hello'.  Writing tools are easily changable as you go with 'extras' little more than the cost of a similar paper notepad. Editing facilities are excellent with erasing / box drag select sections.  When done notes can be sent to the cloud in a couple of taps to access from anywhere to whoever selected.

Text: For writing on PDFs with an S-Pen or even text boxes, this is by far the best app.  I tried Adobe Reader, LectureNotes, PDF Max, and EZPDF and none of them gave me the clean and intuitive interface. Few gripes: S-Pen side button note working. Both Lecture Notes and INKreadible support the s-pen button (can't the Devs do something atleast for rooted GMD users?) No easy way to preview pages in a large document. One-finger eraser size cannot be set. Bluetooth keyboard should override pen-only setting. (i. e you should be able to click somewhere with the mouse and input text even if ignoring finger input) ....all and all, worth hefty price of the premium features........still no s pen button support

Text: This is an excellent app - in that it provides good features and executes them beautifully. Features = import bookmarks and annotate them in all ways; make free-form notes and notebooks; export all kinds of note-documents into PDF;  Save; and then Share them via email or adding to Dropbox.   The feature I feel is missing is "automatic syncing to Dropbox" -- I find it so many times that I want to access my docs somewhere, and have not explicitly Exported them. There needs to be a way to control this feature - basically, I want to designate a document to be always sync'd to Dropbox by default. That is, the "Save" command should function as Sync. Also, it should remember where in my Dropbox folder structure the document should go.

Text: I really love the infinite scrolling. It's a much more natural way of taking notes on a tablet, if that makes any sense. I''ve found S Note to be pretty annoying because the pages are ridiculously small and I would have to have countless pages just for one lecture of notes. Whereas, with infinite scrolling, I can keep on going uninterrupted, or I can add another page if the topic changes or if I just feel that it's getting too long.  This would be 5 stars if the S pen wrote more smoothly on the app. It writes well enough, but for someone who is OCD it gets rather irritating. Could this please be fixed? The S pen, writes amazingly well on the S Note application, but it feels a bit jerky on this application.

Text: It's a good note taking app and the second best on the market. It falls way short on the drawing tools and the ability to save custom pens. I'm in college and use lecturenotes because the custom tools and ability to save pens makes taking notes in class a breeze. It also lacks the ability lecture has with organization (keywords, indexing, and search) it's almost there, but needs some fine tuning. A really good app though and I did pay for all the additional features. If you need a basic note taking app and don't require a lot of extras or intense organization this is the one for you. I do like the actual flow of writing in this app better than lecture, but without the other features I have to place this as a backup.

Text: I use this for all my lecture notes and research scribble. PDF import/export doesn't destroy links or text. I use it for signing my signature to forms and adding light notes to PDFs, but more commonly use ebookdroid for reading them. This is a constantly improving app, but it's worth the money right now if you do a lot of writing.  Until it reaches some kind of final form, expect a kind of a la carte approach to the biggest features. There are many free updates, though it doesn't seem that handwriting recognition is coming any time soon.

Text: S-Note is ok, but after Samsung dropped support for importing PDF's, I gave up on it. Papyrus works perfect for dealing with PDF documents. Text: Having now tried pretty much every 3+ star rated handwritten note-style app in the marketplace, I can confidently say that this is the best one by a LONG shot.  To be clear, I use a Galaxy Note 10.1 - and with that form factor in mind (i.e., an active pen), it's fantastic for note taking.  It also works very well as an ebook - provided you load them in as PDFs.  It could use some features to round out its usability - but I mean this in the sense of MS Office needing improvements, not NeoOffice - that is to say: the tool is complete as is and very good, but obviously it's not perfect.  If you're looking for an all-purpose handwriting app, I HIGHLY recommend getting it.

Text: Nice app but has functionality limitations that make it a no-go for me: * The toolbar isn't permanently visible, so it takes several clicks to switch between the various tools. Gets really clunky when you need to switch regularly. * No scroll by swiping, and no continuous page display  * Page navigation is done by either hitting the forward or back key , or pressing the page number and spinning through all the pages - takes forever on a large document  * Phone app freezes on large PDFs  *Zoom level doesn't hold when you change pages  * Pasting text from other apps doesn't wrap the text - just sticks it in as one long line Lecturenotes has a bigger learning curve but provides all of this and lots more, so I've adopted that as may primary note taking app.

Text: I use Papyrus on my Samsung 12.2 pro for mindmapping. The "infinite" paper setting allows you to map ideas without limit, zooming in and out as you need. Great for taking interview notes as you never have to find another piece of paper. Then send to pdf, print and off you go. I love writing with the stylus and erasing with my finger! A few more tricks that other software has got (smarter page turning, thumbnails to scan for the right page, and saved pen pre-sets, bookmark tabs) would be great additions and then it would outclass any rivals for journal writers.
text: i use papyrus on my samsung pro for mindmapping the infinite paper setting allows you to map ideas without limit zooming in and out as you need great for taking interview notes as you never have to find another piece of paper then send to pdf print and off you go i love writing with the stylus and erasing with my finger a few more tricks that other software has got smarter page turning thumbnails to scan for the right page and saved pen presets bookmark tabs would be great additions and then it would outclass any rivals for journal writers

Text: I use Papyrus to take notes during meetings and, increasingly, in place of paper notes while working on design problems. I'll then often use it to compose better organized, more readable versions of those notes to share with team members.  It's almost as transparent a tool for recording thoughts as pen and paper but can be easily backed up with all the other digital assets that go with a project as well as duplicated and shared with others.  Being vector based makes the notes much more editable and a higher visual quality than those created by Samsung's S-Note.  My only problem at this point is that the number of notes I've created is adding up and the tools for organizing them aren't as powerful as I'd prefer. Notes can be organized into notebooks but the ability to nest those groupings or tag notes for sorting and filtering would help a lot for some of my larger projects.
text: i use papyrus to take notes during meetings and increasingly in place of paper notes while working on design problems ill then often use it to compose better organized more readable versions of those notes to share with team members its almost as transparent a tool for recording thoughts as pen and paper but can be easily backed up with all the other digital assets that go with a project as well as duplicated and shared with others being vector based makes the notes much more editable and a higher visual quality than those created by samsungs snote my only problem at this point is that the number of notes ive created is adding up and the tools for organizing them arent as powerful as id prefer notes can be organized into notebooks but the ability to nest those groupings or tag notes for sorting and filtering would help a lot for some of my larger projects

Text: Positives: Writing notes, editing, cutting & pasting elements all work very smoothly & intuitively (apart from a couple a things). Dropbox and synching of pdfs is great & means I have access to pdfs of all my notes on multiple desktops. The folder view has an image of the 1st page, which makes it very easy to find what you are looking for.  Negatives : No way to insert a blank page!! when switching back to the writing/ pen tool, from say the selection tool it brings up the pen options dialog, which has to be dismissed before you can start writing again. Wider cloud support would be good. Changing the behavior of some actions didn't work ; it would be nice if the pen right click allowed you to select objects (ala OneNote). Can't import vector graphic files like eps or svg, so images (in particular plots from say Matlab) don't look great, but is usable.

Text: Papyrus is a great experience if you're only looking at the free version. I love the two finger scroll and zoom and single finger erase functions - they make note taking so much more streamlined and easy to use! I love how zooming in doesn't fuzz up the writing, which is something I had a serious issue with in LectureNotes. The only problem with Papyrus is that its extra features aren't even that great, and are definitely not worth the price especially when compared to other note taking apps in the market. I also wish there was an audio recording function, because taking notes to a professor speaking is a great tool to have. When other apps in the market have this capability, and at a much lower price than what Papyrus currently offers even without this capability, you know that there needs to be some fixing. I'm definitely regretting purchasing these premium features, and would refund if possible. I love taking plain notes on Papyrus though, and that will keep me using the app for future use.

Text: The whole point of a pdf import, for me at least, was to be able to markup a pdf already on my tablet, so when my tablet syncs with my office network, the file backs up and replaces the older file in the office network. Importing the pdf creates a new file within Papyrus that has no relation to the original. To actually use the markups, I need to pay even more for the cloud storage, which only syncs with Box and Dropbox (and from what I see in the reviews, that's not working all that well either.) So then I'd have to make the cloud version sync with the office version, and then sync that with my tablet. Way too much file duplication to bother with.   Now, if I could use Papyrus's tools to markup an existing pdf without the need to import it and create a new note, then that would be very nice. Otherwise, it leaves me feeling that the developers were being short sighted, greedy, and selfish, forcing us to pay to use the pdf function, and then forcing us to pay to actually do anything with the documents after Papyrus gets a hold of it.
text: the whole point of a pdf import for me at least was to be able to markup a pdf already on my tablet so when my tablet syncs with my office network the file backs up and replaces the older file in the office network importing the pdf creates a new file within papyrus that has no relation to the original to actually use the markups i need to pay even more for the cloud storage which only syncs with box and dropbox and from what i see in the reviews thats not working all that well either so then id have to make the cloud version sync with the office version and then sync that with my tablet way too much file duplication to bother with now if i could use papyruss tools to markup an existing pdf without the need to import it and create a new note then that would be very nice otherwise it leaves me feeling that the developers were being short sighted greedy and selfish forcing us to pay to use the pdf function and then forcing us to pay to actually do anything with the documents after papyrus gets a hold of it

Text: This app had the potential to be a really great tool for note taking.  However, after purchasing the premium shapes and text addon, I was very surprised at just how basic these 'premium' features were!  The text tool doesn't support wrapping - a bare minimum when you are writing text onto a page.  Text is also entered into a separate edit window instead of directly onto the page.  Shape drawing doesn't even support filled shapes!  The app also doesn't support any form of transparency for items that are drawn.  So you can't use a pen as a highlighter for example.  Lots of things that should improve just to say that it supports basic features.
text: this app had the potential to be a really great tool for note taking however after purchasing the premium shapes and text addon i was very surprised at just how basic these premium features were the text tool doesnt support wrapping a bare minimum when you are writing text onto a page text is also entered into a separate edit window instead of directly onto the page shape drawing doesnt even support filled shapes the app also doesnt support any form of transparency for items that are drawn so you cant use a pen as a highlighter for example lots of things that should improve just to say that it supports basic features

Text: Makes good use of the S pen API.  And probably the only app that feels closest to natural writing on paper.  I don't like zoom boxes or zooming in general when I write.  I prefer zoom locking so I have some idea of how large or small my hand writing is.  I love the page size limits so i know when i reach the edge of a page and need to get a new page.  This is a must for making printouts of my notes.  Also I have a tendency to rest my wrist on the device as if it was paper and it doesn't activate other functions like zoom or starts using my wrist to continue writing.  I love this feature the best because I don't need to suspend my wrist and write in this unnatural unergonomic manner.  I don't know  about other people, writing with my wrist suspended causes me physical pain so this is the only usable note taking app I can use without hurting my wrist. I wish an iOS version of this existed and some how had the same ergonomic feature as this. The only drawback is that there is no option to delete pages within the notes.  And other minir features like moving and inserting pages would be nice, but if I could at least delete pages, even as a premium feature I would buy.

Text: Update: The newest update of the app finally brings the ability to import PDFs and mark them up as you see fit... as a premium feature in which you have to pay for in order to utilize. This wouldn't be a big deal if it were a similar price to the other two features ($2 at the time I purchased them),  but for so reason,  the developers thought that a feature that comes standard in several other note takings apps was worth their customers paying an additional $5 for it. Papyrus may have the edge when it comes to how well it writes, but it definitely costs a hefty price ($9 if you want all of the features). 2 stars.   Original review: This is a great app overall. Improvements such as the ability to import/edit PDF files would make this leaps and bounds better than other competing note taking applications. Very responsive when writing with a stylus.   Another huge gripe that I have with the existing version of  Papyrus is the lack of S-Pen functionality. Yes,  I know that the developer claims that Samsung has prevented third-party developers from utilizing S-Pen button actions,  but I have seen other third party applications make use of it,  so forgive me if I'm not entirely convinced.

Text: I have found the Papyrus app better for my journal writing than the S-note app that comes with my Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 tablet. Papyrus allows setting the page size to 8.5x11. With the tablet in landscape orientation, the 8.5" width of the screen means I can write in the same scale as on standard paper with a traditional pen. The app also provides a greater range of pen line widths, has better pressure sensitivity, and it's a vector program that exports a much sharper page to PDF than the S-note's jpeg-based export. Print-outs look very much like my old hand-written pages. Also, Papyrus PDF pages can be opened in Adobe Illustrator for more advanced editing of the vector-based lines if desired.
text: i have found the papyrus app better for my journal writing than the snote app that comes with my samsung galaxy note tablet papyrus allows setting the page size to x with the tablet in landscape orientation the width of the screen means i can write in the same scale as on standard paper with a traditional pen the app also provides a greater range of pen line widths has better pressure sensitivity and its a vector program that exports a much sharper page to pdf than the snotes jpegbased export printouts look very much like my old handwritten pages also papyrus pdf pages can be opened in adobe illustrator for more advanced editing of the vectorbased lines if desired

Text: Papyrus may not be as feature rich as the S Note app version that originally shipped with my Note 2 and Note 10.1 2012 but...and apologies for the Samsung rant...  Since my Note 2 updated to Android 4.3, the new version of S Note (with less features, and new file format I can't use on my Note 10.1 2012), and the Samsung cloud features which no longer reliably support the inter device syncing I rely on are corrupting my note files (feels like a cynical move by Samsung to force me to buy new hardware or maybe just a really really badly planned rollout). I therefore decided to look for an alternative that didn't tie me to Samsung software or a never materialising Android upgrade for my Note 10.1 2012 (love their hardware but can't trust their abilities to reliably provide compatible software for a tablet I have only owned for 9 months)  Papyrus is absolutely that alternative. The pen tracking is way better than S Note. S Note always was a tiny bit off. What appeared on the screen was never exactly aligned with the S Pen nib. With Papyrus it is so spot on and faster too. When combined with the exceptional pressure sensing using Papyrus is like writing with pencil and paper. Superb.
text: papyrus may not be as feature rich as the s note app version that originally shipped with my note and note butand apologies for the samsung rant since my note updated to android the new version of s note with less features and new file format i cant use on my note and the samsung cloud features which no longer reliably support the inter device syncing i rely on are corrupting my note files feels like a cynical move by samsung to force me to buy new hardware or maybe just a really really badly planned rollout i therefore decided to look for an alternative that didnt tie me to samsung software or a never materialising android upgrade for my note love their hardware but cant trust their abilities to reliably provide compatible software for a tablet i have only owned for months papyrus is absolutely that alternative the pen tracking is way better than s note s note always was a tiny bit off what appeared on the screen was never exactly aligned with the s pen nib with papyrus it is so spot on and faster too when combined with the exceptional pressure sensing using papyrus is like writing with pencil and paper superb

Text: I'm using a Nexus 10 with passive stylus.    This app works ok.  But if you've used Notability for iPad, you will be dissapointed.  Here are some features I would like to see to make this a better app:  The response is slow relative to my ability to write.  This also has the side effect of making the written letters look smaller than the hand motion would have dictated.  Doesn't allow typing in the non-premium version.  Screen does not auto adjust as you move to the edge while writing.  You have to stop what you are doing and manually scroll the page.  There is no highlighter.  Page settings are limited -- no background color change??  No search or OCR support.  I have to zoom the entire page to make a space large enough to write on (Can't write very small with a stylus.) .  So I can only see a tiny bit of my page while I'm writing.    Given the limitations. particularly in the pen response, I'm not motivated to buy the premium version.

Text: The free version is ok and works well, but do not spend the 3 bucks for the tool package. The ability to add text is not a benefit the way this works. Text entry is done via the Samsung yellow area which is fine, but it goes to a little white Preview box until you hit ok. Once you hit ok you will find that the text you entered is in one Continuous line regardless of how you setup your page. You then have to go back to enter return characters which is a hassel, and becomes not possible to edit because you cannot select the entre text line with the Lasso tool. Free APP is good, but the paid part is not worth the 3 bucks. If I could get a refund I'd surely ask for one. If I could I'd give the free App 4 stars, but since I can only give one rating I'm rating what I paid for - big disappointment.

Text: Being that I have not opted for the premium services yet, I'm giving this application a 5 because my I can overlook a couple things I would have liked to have seen.  I like that the application is simple, runs fairly well, and takes up relatively little space.  The backgrounds are classic and not overdone at all; it is very practical (a major plus) being that it is quite reminiscent of writing on actual paper.  It is perfect for anyone who only wants a notepad!  There are only a couple things I would have liked to have seen, though of course, not at all critical:  *Logarithmic paper (just in case). *Something (perhaps at the main page) that tells me the total pages that have writing or are being used by each note. *A way to insert a page between pages. *An option to list each note/notebook as a list instead of tiles so that it may be easier to navigate a large number of them.  Overall, the app is very functional and I use it all the time for just about everything.

Text: Papyrus is an amazing notetaking app. Instant erase and undo/redo with one touch. You can transition from pen to finger to erase in a split second. Almost all other note apps require a tool change for this function. I can't even begin to describe how much faster this makes Papyrus compared to everything else.   The page layouts are minimalist and simple. Controls are intuitive and sparse. This is a notetaking app. We don't need all that extra BS. You can either see an overview at a glance, or scroll through the pages one at a time. The interface is blazingly fast to navigate! The notes simply save when you move to another page or quit. No time wasting prompts, no hand holding       My only complaint is that the pen isn't as responsive and quick as the Autodesk Sketchbook App. It may have something to do with these types of apps vectorizing the writing, rather than the raster ouput in Sketchbook.    Otherwise, this is easily the greatest note-taking app available for Android.
text: papyrus is an amazing notetaking app instant erase and undoredo with one touch you can transition from pen to finger to erase in a split second almost all other note apps require a tool change for this function i cant even begin to describe how much faster this makes papyrus compared to everything else the page layouts are minimalist and simple controls are intuitive and sparse this is a notetaking app we dont need all that extra bs you can either see an overview at a glance or scroll through the pages one at a time the interface is blazingly fast to navigate the notes simply save when you move to another page or quit no time wasting prompts no hand holding my only complaint is that the pen isnt as responsive and quick as the autodesk sketchbook app it may have something to do with these types of apps vectorizing the writing rather than the raster ouput in sketchbook otherwise this is easily the greatest notetaking app available for android

Text: Overall good note taking app, I use it to take notes in school in each of my classes. l am in the sciences, so being able to write everything out is very useful for diagrams and illustrations. However, this app could use more tools to improve functionality. For example, a fill tool would be nice, as well as the ability to correct shapes into proper proportions like some othernote taking apps. l also purchased the upgraded tools pack, but all it allows you to do is draw a straight line , rectangle or circle. More features included in this pack would definitely improve my rating. live also recently had an issue inserting images into my notes lately. The app has been crashing when I try to add images, however, this is something that can be patched, so I haven't deducted any points for my review. I would rate this app 7/10 until more Features are added. (Dev Hint : have a look at iOs's Notability and borrow a few features)

Text: As a student I've tried almost all of the handwriting apps available and so far papyrus has had the best functionality. The handwriting recognition is a lot more precise than other apps and it does well with inserting pictures without being overloaded. I used S Note for a while and even though it had great options and tools, it stopped saving if there were too many pages or pictures inserted. The one thing I'd love to see in Papyrus is more aesthetically pleasing page backgrounds. A lot of the other handwriting apps have multiple design and color options. Even a softer cream colored background would be a great improvement to the stark white they have now. Other than that, it's great! Perfect for taking notes during lectures and studying from later on.

Text: Why isn't Samsung Note tablet native drawing Ul/API this simple and unobtrusive? Two actual usability issues: 1) Even if a note is stored in a folder, recent notes does not show the name of the folder the note is in. Sometimes I move a note in a folder and because of a motoric error it ends up in the wrong folder. Since there is no "sort notes by last moved to folder", it gets really hard to find a note in such situation. 2) Accidental generation of notes: I often press the add new note button without thinking. Then I perhaps leave papyrus on in the background. I end up closing the note at some point but don't remember if I wrote something in it. Then it gets annoying since I need to check if the note has contents - that does not necessarily show in the note icon - before deleting the note, to make sure I don't delete anything that matters. So not saving notes at all before they have any content or their name set would probably be a good idea.  Also, I would like a fill tool. I understand it may go against your philosophy but really, in practice, I often want a coloured canvas to paint on first for example. Or just fill a shape.

Text: The pressure sensitivity of the s-pen doesn't work as well.  Half of the time, the software does not recognize that the pen tip is on the tablet when I am writing.  Also, when it does,  the strokes start of either heavy and then abruptly turn skinny OR vice versa. There isn't a smooth transition even if I smoothly apply pressure or slowly let go of the pressure.  Also, the brush strokes are "twitchy".  I think every s-pen for the samsung note 8 OR the 10.1 version have a little bit of give on the tip -- very, very slight give because of the pressure sensitivity mechanism (I have both s-pen versions) .  When writing on the tablet, this "give' causes the brush strokes to not be smooth; I think the stock samsung software accounts for this and slightly smooths out the strokes making my hand written notes look a lot better and more natural.  However,  the stock software doesn't do copy and paste.  The Papyrus software does and it does it really well.  This is one of the reason why I tried Papyrus.. I hope the author continues to work on Papyrus though.  Even with all the negatives, it is a good program...

Text: I use Papyrus on a daily basis because it is very good. Still I only rate it 2stars because it is still missing the basic functionality that every note taking app has.  For example: it is impossible to see if a note has a next page or not. You just have to try in each note you open to press the next button. If you get a blank page then there was no next page... Gets very annoying after a time. How difficult can it be to just put an indicator like "page 1of 6"?  There is also no way the system remembers your zoom-level. I like to zoom out on a page when I open a note to see all the contents on a page. Then, when going to the next page, it forgets about this and zooms back tot the default. If you quickly want to browse through the pages of a note to look for something, then you have to zoom out or pan on every page of the note. I am getting really tired of this.   The developer seems to be concentrating on adding more advanced features, but forgets about the basics.  The good part of Papyrus is the actual writing. The most fluid and easy to use of all the apps I tried. The fact that you get a nice PDF copy in your dropbox is a killer feature.
text: i use papyrus on a daily basis because it is very good still i only rate it stars because it is still missing the basic functionality that every note taking app has for example it is impossible to see if a note has a next page or not you just have to try in each note you open to press the next button if you get a blank page then there was no next page gets very annoying after a time how difficult can it be to just put an indicator like page of there is also no way the system remembers your zoomlevel i like to zoom out on a page when i open a note to see all the contents on a page then when going to the next page it forgets about this and zooms back tot the default if you quickly want to browse through the pages of a note to look for something then you have to zoom out or pan on every page of the note i am getting really tired of this the developer seems to be concentrating on adding more advanced features but forgets about the basics the good part of papyrus is the actual writing the most fluid and easy to use of all the apps i tried the fact that you get a nice pdf copy in your dropbox is a killer feature

Text: This app has finally allowed me to let go of my paper notepads. The combination of Papyrus and The Galaxy Note devices (I have the 2 and the 10) is the first time I've gotten the same tactile feeling from a device as I get from pencil and paper. Add that to the infinite, vector based format of Papyrus notes, the graph or lined backgrounds, cloud storage, the masking tool, color and brush options... You end up with the next evolution in note-taking. The only (tiny) drawback has been the load times for some of my larger notes - the trade off for infinite page space is a few seconds loading it up. This can easily be avoided with proper organization, however. The app is of excellent quality, and I am grateful to the developers for improving the way I work and create.
text: this app has finally allowed me to let go of my paper notepads the combination of papyrus and the galaxy note devices i have the and the is the first time ive gotten the same tactile feeling from a device as i get from pencil and paper add that to the infinite vector based format of papyrus notes the graph or lined backgrounds cloud storage the masking tool color and brush options you end up with the next evolution in notetaking the only tiny drawback has been the load times for some of my larger notes the trade off for infinite page space is a few seconds loading it up this can easily be avoided with proper organization however the app is of excellent quality and i am grateful to the developers for improving the way i work and create

Text: An excellent program for note taking.The best feature that I like is that the page is endless.  Most other programs have this limitation that you need to change pages after you have run out of the little area that you have. But the biggest limitation is that the program does not allow saving on the cloud in the native format.  So if I format my phone,  then I only have pdf or jpg versions of the file which I can view but cannot edit. This means that effectively I lose my work each time that I factory reset.

Text: This app is excellent to use on a samsung galaxy note 10.1 for class notes. I bought the premium features for backup and additional tools, of which I use the shape tools the most. I first started out with lecture notes app but found that the vector based papyrus was superior in visual fidelity. I gave up some good features in lecture notes but I'm hopeful the features of papyrus expand.  One feature I would like to see implemented is tagging notes/notebooks with topic,  keywords for easy search.   I would also like to see the ability to import (and annotate) pdfs. This would greatly help with natural flow because pdfs are currently handled by another app and I would prefer my notes all in one place.

Text: Papyrus easily has the best user interface out of all the notetaking apps I've used to date on my ThinkPad Tablet. I've been a heavy OneNote user for years on my Windows machines, and Papyrus is the only thing on Android that can match its freedom of input.  From the point of view of a OneNote user, however, Papyrus still has its problems. First and foremost, it lacks search. Second, it only outputs PDF, JPG and PNG and imports nothing, so you can't switch between devices or collaborate with anyone who doesn't happen to own a pen-enabled Android tablet. Third, its palm rejection and zoom will join forces to make you lose your place in the note.  That said, Papyrus is a dream to use; it's design is leagues ahead of other pen-enabled notetaking apps, especially the dismal Android OneNote client. I only wish that Papyrus was a little more aware of the notetaking world around it.

Text: I use Papyrus at work on my Note II for sketching out ideas, process blueprinting, and writing up mock tutorials. Since the latest update, I can import screen captures from other apps.  Probably the part about Papyrus that sets it apart from other note-taking apps is that you can create infinitely-sized notes simply by two-finger dragging the page to create new space. You have no idea how useful it is to not be restrained by page size when you're working on a small device.  Sometimes my note gets so large after working on it for a while and I start to see where things could be broken down into smaller parts. I would love to see a feature where you could break apart a single page into multiple pages based upon a selection.

Text: This is my note app of choice - it is the closest thing to a perfect experience that I have found. There only a few things standing in the way of this app being ideal for my needs. It makes lecture notes viable even on the relatively small screen of the note 2. It looks like there is active development of the app, so it should keep getting better. A list of things I found to be nice/not nice: Awesome:  (1) Palm rejection  (2) Infinite page both down and to the side  (3) Can use fingers to resize/move while taking notes  (4) Pressure sensitive to S pen  (5) No tools on bottom of screen  in landscape mode  (6) Can add pictures into note page.    Not-yet-awesome:  (1) S pen side button does not work (not their fault)  (2) No single finger scrolling  (3) Scrolling takes a second to load different parts of a page  (4) Cloud services (in app purchase) does not yet have Google Drive.  (5) Can't save notes to SD card  (6) Writing does not seem as smooth as in S note (S note seems to do smoothing)
text: this is my note app of choice it is the closest thing to a perfect experience that i have found there only a few things standing in the way of this app being ideal for my needs it makes lecture notes viable even on the relatively small screen of the note it looks like there is active development of the app so it should keep getting better a list of things i found to be nicenot nice awesome palm rejection infinite page both down and to the side can use fingers to resizemove while taking notes pressure sensitive to s pen no tools on bottom of screen in landscape mode can add pictures into note page notyetawesome s pen side button does not work not their fault no single finger scrolling scrolling takes a second to load different parts of a page cloud services in app purchase does not yet have google drive cant save notes to sd card writing does not seem as smooth as in s note s note seems to do smoothing

Text: a) Export to PDF, JPEG, or PNG for viewing, editing, and sharing on other devices b) Pressure sensitive (S-pen) for fluid writing and hand drawings c) Use multiple tools at once -Draw with stylus -Select with stylus button -Erase with single-finger -Pan/Zoom with double-finger  d) Cut, copy, paste single or multiple selected markings  I use it for writing engineering/physics notes during lecture and I couldnt ask for anything more (we write about 6 pages of 8.5x11 notes in 1 hour lecture). I can quickly draw a design using freehand or line/box/circle tools, adjust thickness/color and add text. Holding the S-pen button, I can quickly select a component (one marking or a group of markings) and resize it and and change color, thickness, etc. Also while selected, you can CUT, COPY, DUPLICATE, and PASTE groups of markings, even between different notes. This amazing feature allows me to select an engineering problem and replicate into a new note, to start a new problem with a similar setup, to expand in detail on that problem, or even make several altered versions of one design with changing the original. This is also great in problem solving, for repeating symbols and equations

Text: I love the notebook workflow, the ability to have multiple pages in a note, the configurable page size. I love being able to both draw and type. I think the freemium model and prices work. I love being able to sync everything among my devices.  I'm confident my feature requests are already in the pipeline, as I imagine they are common desires.  My current problem with the app, though, which makes it hard to like it all the way, is that when I'm typing long notes, the app occasionally freezes when I hit the 'done' button and I lose everything I just typed. Only seems to happen with long notes with many lines of text, but that is a huge part of what I use the app for.

Text: Using on my Asus Transformer TF101, and while I know it's old, I have used other handwriting apps (FreeNote) and they are much faster than this.  It is so bad, that a letter does not render until I have nearly finished it when I am writing at normal speed.  This makes it very difficult to write legibly, and to do so, I have to write very slowly.  There are not a lot of configuration options, so I tried making sure there was nothing else loading down the tablet, and I also tried three different styli.  Nothing seemed to help.  It's unfortunate, because I really like the interface, which is my main gripe with FreeNote, but it looks like for now that the devs chose form over function.  When this is optimized, I would consider installing it again.  The form is nice, the function needs work.

Text: Of all the note apps that I've tried, Papyrus Beta has the most natural interface for my tastes.  Accessing and changing tools and changing basic pen settings are quick because there are  minimal steps to navigate features.  Unfortunately, there is noticeable delay between my stylus input and the appearance of writing strokes.  I don't notice the delay in Quill or Samsung SNote, but I spend time waiting for Papyrus Beta to to register pen strokes.  Though the awesome interface is worth money, I'm reluctant to spend $10 to unlock features if the most basic need, quick and smooth stylus input, is not met.  Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1

Text: Papyrus is an application designed to do but one thing, and do it well: handwritten notes. It uses pressure-sensitive strokes within its own pen-nib framework (NOT using the common S-Pen palette) and stores the strokes in a vector format(‼) so filesizes are incredibly small, even to hundreds of pages per notebook. It doesn't do anything beyond handwritten notes, and users should not consider it a replacement to or competitor of S-Note/S-Memo or comparable all-in-one apps, but rather as a complement to a notation suite. Also, and crucially, this app is free and totally uninfected by ads or crippled features, the single upsell-scheme a discreet Settings mention for cloud-storage integration (and should the ad push ever become more obtrusive I will retract my rating). This is an outstanding application for those with pen devices.
text: papyrus is an application designed to do but one thing and do it well handwritten notes it uses pressuresensitive strokes within its own pennib framework not using the common spen palette and stores the strokes in a vector format so filesizes are incredibly small even to hundreds of pages per notebook it doesnt do anything beyond handwritten notes and users should not consider it a replacement to or competitor of snotesmemo or comparable allinone apps but rather as a complement to a notation suite also and crucially this app is free and totally uninfected by ads or crippled features the single upsellscheme a discreet settings mention for cloudstorage integration and should the ad push ever become more obtrusive i will retract my rating this is an outstanding application for those with pen devices

Papyrus should come standard on any tablet with a stylus.

Text: This APP is great and quite reliable on The HTC-One-S phone (HTC has a 1.6 GHz. 2-core). My only difficulty has been the lateral sheet navigation ( when sheet is huge compared to the small portion which is shown on the display). Instead of using 2-fingers, a possible alternative, is to introduce a LABS-type pop-up buttons .... when stickyFinger touches the extreme Left edge or Right edge of display, about 85% down towards the bottom edge. When the LABS button menu pops-up, user can toggle between "simple stylus navigation" or "writing mode". Then, navigation can be done easily with one finger or simply using the passive Stylus pointer. An alternative might also be to add the toggle setting (mentioned above) to the parameters menu ( existing... 3-dot menu) as a 6th item in the list. Thanks for this great App ;

Text: This is simpler but seems more powerful and customisable than the default Samsung app S Memo. Most notable is the app can make a distinction between finger and pen, simple lined paper background among others, and infinite paper size which is super useful. Also pen button is not fully working as expected in this app. Another interesting difference from S Memo is the drawings are stored as vector instead of bitmap.

Text: I been using drawing apps for diagramming and design extensively on my iPad (Notes Plus was the fav and also tried Noteshelf, SketchPad HD, Penultimate and a few others).  After getting my Nexus 7, I wanted to get rid of the iPad.  The deal breaker was losing out on the quality drawing experience, so I was delighted to discover Papyrus!  It is simply night and day better than all of them due to sheer ease of use and power within a simple UI... and at version 0.2.1 this is remarkable.  I've tried other Android drawing apps and naturally didn't find anything close.  So, I use it day in and out and it hasn't failed.  I'm very excited for new features as they are released (looking forward to resizing selected objects, text boxes, etc.) and hoping it keeps to the same elegant usability.

Text: I got my Galaxy Note 10.1 and have been looking around for good handwriting applications. This does what I want and nothing more, nothing less. It stores writing as vector graphics which is nice for resizing things, supports pressure sensitivity, allows erasing with finger touch and writing with stylus. Has notebooks and notes for organization, pretty standard. Exports to PDF. What more do you need?  The only thing I would like would be to have support for buttons on pens to use as an eraser but using my finger is intuitive enough. And maybe customizable spaced lines (I'd like something half the size of the narrowest line spacing to line up my letters better, like AntiPaper Notes has).

Text: This is still a beta.  An impressive beta.  A useable beta.  But beta nonetheless.  What it offers is a clean interface and a good inking experience.    What sets it apart from other note apps is the great support for active pens.  The availability of customizable gestures is fantastic.  Palm recognition is good.  The finger navigation works reliably, unlike other note apps like Quill.  All the below notwithstanding, this is the best note taking app on the market.  What I'd love to see (and pay for) in subsequent versions:  - Sync with other devices.  Not just export PDFs to dropbox, but have up-to-date editable notebooks available on both my phone and tablet (and desktop -- one day?)  - Hi-lighters  - The ability to reorganize notebook order on the home screen.  Right now they're just chronological.  - Better eraser.  Now it's a fixed number of pixels, regardless of zoom.  Would rather have it scale, to erase fine strokes more easily.  - Ability to adjust ink stroke properties (e.g. color) after it's on paper.  - "Handwriting mode" (option to get rid of pressure sensitivity.  Important for drawing, less so for writing.)  - Over-rule auto screen timeout.
text: this is still a beta an impressive beta a useable beta but beta nonetheless what it offers is a clean interface and a good inking experience what sets it apart from other note apps is the great support for active pens the availability of customizable gestures is fantastic palm recognition is good the finger navigation works reliably unlike other note apps like quill all the below notwithstanding this is the best note taking app on the market what id love to see and pay for in subsequent versions sync with other devices not just export pdfs to dropbox but have uptodate editable notebooks available on both my phone and tablet and desktop one day hilighters the ability to reorganize notebook order on the home screen right now theyre just chronological better eraser now its a fixed number of pixels regardless of zoom would rather have it scale to erase fine strokes more easily ability to adjust ink stroke properties eg color after its on paper handwriting mode option to get rid of pressure sensitivity important for drawing less so for writing overrule auto screen timeout

Text: I love papyrus, it does what S memo / note cannot: use vectors.  If you annotate a picture with S memo and then send it to somebody, they get a nasty surprise as all is pixelated. S memo / S note uses pixels and uses a pretty low resolution, nothing you can ever scale up without it looking really ugly. Papyrus on the other hand uses vectors, which are infinite scalable, you can print it out real big and it won't look ugly. You can also zoom in and out and scroll to make the note bigger in all directions. I use this on the Galaxy Note and love the precision it has with the stylus. Now just please add the annotation feature and I will be forever happy ;-) As this is a beta and it works really well and it is free, I will give this 5 stars. If the annotation feature makes it, I will even buy the app. Keep up the good work guys!
text: i love papyrus it does what s memo note cannot use vectors if you annotate a picture with s memo and then send it to somebody they get a nasty surprise as all is pixelated s memo s note uses pixels and uses a pretty low resolution nothing you can ever scale up without it looking really ugly papyrus on the other hand uses vectors which are infinite scalable you can print it out real big and it wont look ugly you can also zoom in and out and scroll to make the note bigger in all directions i use this on the galaxy note and love the precision it has with the stylus now just please add the annotation feature and i will be forever happy as this is a beta and it works really well and it is free i will give this stars if the annotation feature makes it i will even buy the app keep up the good work guys

Text: I was using this on Galaxy Note, it is hands down the best pen app in Android. I'm an extensive Onenote2010 user on a tablet PC. Why can't Samsung make something like this? Why can't Microsoft add inking in Onenote? I didn't have my hopes high, but Papyrus is really easy to use for writing notes with the pen, and quickly erasing with fingers is very easy. Can't believe this app didn't win first prize on Samsung Spen developer contest.  The only con that I see for now is that it doesn't support ICS, so I'm stuck with the sucky slow/lagging Samsung S-note app. I'm actually not writing any notes for now. ICS, there's also an option to show where the pointer dot is so it'll get even better once Papyrus supports ICS.  For the future, it would be nice if it can sync notes on Dropbox or somewhere on the cloud so that I don't lose the notes. A PC version note viewer/PDF converter would be nice too.
text: i was using this on galaxy note it is hands down the best pen app in android im an extensive onenote user on a tablet pc why cant samsung make something like this why cant microsoft add inking in onenote i didnt have my hopes high but papyrus is really easy to use for writing notes with the pen and quickly erasing with fingers is very easy cant believe this app didnt win first prize on samsung spen developer contest the only con that i see for now is that it doesnt support ics so im stuck with the sucky slowlagging samsung snote app im actually not writing any notes for now ics theres also an option to show where the pointer dot is so itll get even better once papyrus supports ics for the future it would be nice if it can sync notes on dropbox or somewhere on the cloud so that i dont lose the notes a pc version note viewerpdf converter would be nice too

Text: I have been using this App for some days and I am very well impressed. The writing with SPen is very responsive and smooth. It is far better than Skich and it provides features that overcome S Memo's limitations. However, to be a full fledged note taking App, it should also include the following features:  - detect & enhance basic shapes (oval, rectangle, triangle, etc) - import images/photos as objects - resize/rotate of objects or groups of objects - export notes/notebooks in jpg/png (its interesting for those who wish a better integration with Evernote) - export notes in standard vector graphics format (e.g., svg) - additional brush/pen types (e.g., highlight marker, pencil, paint brush, etc) - Pinch to zoom
text: i have been using this app for some days and i am very well impressed the writing with spen is very responsive and smooth it is far better than skich and it provides features that overcome s memos limitations however to be a full fledged note taking app it should also include the following features detect enhance basic shapes oval rectangle triangle etc import imagesphotos as objects resizerotate of objects or groups of objects export notesnotebooks in jpgpng its interesting for those who wish a better integration with evernote export notes in standard vector graphics format eg svg additional brushpen types eg highlight marker pencil paint brush etc pinch to zoom

Text: Let me be clear: this is the best implementation I've seen of the S Pen by far. It leaves Samsung's own S Memo far behind, at least until that Premium Suite drops.  Pressure sensitivity actually works and shows several levels. Notes can be expanded with two-finger scrolling both vertically and horizontally. Transition between landscape and portrait mode is seamless. I don't know how they do it, but the pen just seems to work better than on any other app. All of the other note-taking apps, especially those using the keyboard, are dead to me.  And of course then you have the beautiful, simple user interface that lets you do the things you actually want to do with one click.  It's clear that the creator wants to be make something more than "another note-taking app", so I'm sure there are a lot more features coming. Although it's not adequate for heavy drawing, but then there are other aps for that. And for now it's all free!
text: let me be clear this is the best implementation ive seen of the s pen by far it leaves samsungs own s memo far behind at least until that premium suite drops pressure sensitivity actually works and shows several levels notes can be expanded with twofinger scrolling both vertically and horizontally transition between landscape and portrait mode is seamless i dont know how they do it but the pen just seems to work better than on any other app all of the other notetaking apps especially those using the keyboard are dead to me and of course then you have the beautiful simple user interface that lets you do the things you actually want to do with one click its clear that the creator wants to be make something more than another notetaking app so im sure there are a lot more features coming although its not adequate for heavy drawing but then there are other aps for that and for now its all free

Text: I've got an HTC Flyer with the active stylus and I've always wanted something that's more drawing-oriented than the base pen tools that came with device. Papyrus delivers a solid, basic drawing system with user-definable colors, pen sizes and pressure support on the stylus. It's a very, very good start to a more complete drawing/painting application.  While I would love to see some tool variety and a few extra features, I know this tool will be on my Flyer from this point on!
text: ive got an htc flyer with the active stylus and ive always wanted something thats more drawingoriented than the base pen tools that came with device papyrus delivers a solid basic drawing system with userdefinable colors pen sizes and pressure support on the stylus its a very very good start to a more complete drawingpainting application while i would love to see some tool variety and a few extra features i know this tool will be on my flyer from this point on

Text: I wasn't sure how to delete a note, so wrote to them and within a few minutes I got back a reply - - "Yes, you can delete notes by long pressing on a note thumbnail in the "notebook view" (main page after launching Papyrus). Delete and rename options will appear in the upper right. You can also click multiple notes in that mode to delete them at the same time. You can also long press on notebooks to rename or delete them as well."  Fantastic customer support.  Highly recommend this app.  Am using it on my Transformer Prime.
text: i wasnt sure how to delete a note so wrote to them and within a few minutes i got back a reply yes you can delete notes by long pressing on a note thumbnail in the notebook view main page after launching papyrus delete and rename options will appear in the upper right you can also click multiple notes in that mode to delete them at the same time you can also long press on notebooks to rename or delete them as well fantastic customer support highly recommend this app am using it on my transformer prime
